Low Density Lattice Codes

Naftali Sommer,  Meir Feder,  and Ofir Shalvi The material in this paper was presented in part in the IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory, Seattle, July 2006, and in part in the Inauguration of the UCSD Information Theory and Applications Center, San Diego, Feb. 2006.
Abstract

Low density lattice codes (LDLC) are novel lattice codes that can be decoded efficiently and approach the capacity of the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel. In LDLC a codeword x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is generated directly at the n𝑛n-dimensional Euclidean space as a linear transformation of a corresponding integer message vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, i.e., x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where 𝑯=𝑮−1𝑯superscript𝑮1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1} is restricted to be sparse. The fact that 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is sparse is utilized to develop a linear-time iterative decoding scheme which attains, as demonstrated by simulations, good error performance within ∼0.5similar-toabsent0.5\sim 0.5dB from capacity at block length of n=100,000𝑛100000n=100,000 symbols. The paper also discusses convergence results and implementation considerations.

Index Terms:
Lattices, lattice codes, iterative decoding, LDPC.

I Introduction

If we take a look at the evolution of codes for binary or finite alphabet channels, it was first shown [1] that channel capacity can be achieved with long random codewords. Then, it was found out [2] that capacity can be achieved via a simpler structure of linear codes. Then, specific families of linear codes were found that are practical and have good minimum Hamming distance (e.g. convolutional codes, cyclic block codes, specific cyclic codes such as BCH and Reed-Solomon codes [4]). Later, capacity achieving schemes were found, which have special structures that allow efficient iterative decoding, such as low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes [5] or turbo codes [6].

If we now take a similar look at continuous alphabet codes for the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, it was first shown [3] that codes with long random Gaussian codewords can achieve capacity. Later, it was shown that lattice codes can also achieve capacity ([7] – [12]). Lattice codes are clearly the Euclidean space analogue of linear codes. Similarly to binary codes, we could expect that specific practical lattice codes will then be developed. However, there was almost no further progress from that point. Specific lattice codes that were found were based on fixed dimensional classical lattices [19] or based on algebraic error correcting codes [13][14], but no significant effort was made in designing lattice codes directly in the Euclidean space or in finding specific capacity achieving lattice codes. Practical coding schemes for the AWGN channel were based on finite alphabet codes.

In [15], “signal codes” were introduced. These are lattice codes, designed directly in the Euclidean space, where the information sequence of integers insubscript𝑖𝑛i_{n}, n=1,2,…𝑛12…n=1,2,... is encoded by convolving it with a fixed signal pattern gnsubscript𝑔𝑛g_{n}, n=1,2,…​d𝑛12…𝑑n=1,2,...d. Signal codes are clearly analogous to convolutional codes, and in particular can work at the AWGN channel cutoff rate with simple sequential decoders. In [16] it is also demonstrated that signal codes can work near the AWGN channel capacity with more elaborated bi-directional decoders. Thus, signal codes provided the first step toward finding effective lattice codes with practical decoders.

Inspired by LDPC codes and in the quest of finding practical capacity achieving lattice codes, we propose in this work “Low Density Lattice Codes” (LDLC). We show that these codes can approach the AWGN channel capacity with iterative decoders whose complexity is linear in block length. In recent years several schemes were proposed for using LDPC over continuous valued channels by either multilevel coding [18] or by non-binary alphabet (e.g. [17]). Unlike these LDPC based schemes, in LDLC both the encoder and the channel use the same real algebra which is natural for the continuous-valued AWGN channel. This feature also simplifies the convergence analysis of the iterative decoder.

The outline of this paper is as follows. Low density lattice codes are first defined in Section II. The iterative decoder is then presented in Section III, followed by convergence analysis of the decoder in Section IV. Then, Section V describes how to choose the LDLC code parameters, and Section VI discusses implementation considerations. The computational complexity of the decoder is then discussed in Section VII, followed by a brief description of encoding and shaping in Section VIII. Simulation results are finally presented in Section IX.

II Basic Definitions and Properties

II-A Lattices and Lattice Codes

An n𝑛n dimensional lattice in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m} is defined as the set of all linear combinations of a given basis of n𝑛n linearly independent vectors in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m} with integer coefficients. The matrix 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G}, whose columns are the basis vectors, is called a generator matrix of the lattice. Every lattice point is therefore of the form x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} is an n𝑛n-dimensional vector of integers. The Voronoi cell of a lattice point is defined as the set of all points that are closer to this point than to any other lattice point. The Voronoi cells of all lattice points are congruent, and for square 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} the volume of the Voronoi cell is equal to d​e​t​(𝑮)𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑮det(\boldsymbol{G}). In the sequel 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} will be used to denote both the lattice and its generator matrix.

A lattice code of dimension n𝑛n is defined by a (possibly shifted) lattice 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m} and a shaping region B⊂ℝm𝐵superscriptℝ𝑚B\subset\mathbb{R}^{m}, where the codewords are all the lattice points that lie within the shaping region B𝐵B. Denote the number of these codewords by N𝑁N. The average transmitted power (per channel use, or per symbol) is the average energy of all codewords, divided by the codeword length m𝑚m. The information rate (in bits/symbol) is l​o​g2​(N)/m𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2𝑁𝑚log_{2}(N)/m.

When using a lattice code for the AWGN channel with power limit P𝑃P and noise variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, the maximal information rate is limited by the capacity 12​log2⁡(1+Pσ2)12subscript21𝑃superscript𝜎2\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}(1+\frac{P}{\sigma^{2}}). Poltyrev [20] considered the AWGN channel without restrictions. If there is no power restriction, code rate is a meaningless measure, since it can be increased without limit. Instead, it was suggested in [20] to use the measure of constellation density, leading to a generalized definition of the capacity as the maximal possible codeword density that can be recovered reliably. When applied to lattices, the generalized capacity implies that there exists a lattice 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} of high enough dimension n𝑛n that enables transmission with arbitrary small error probability, if and only if σ2<|d​e​t​(𝑮)|2n2​π​esuperscript𝜎2𝑛superscript𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑮22𝜋𝑒\sigma^{2}<\frac{\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{G})|^{2}}}{2\pi e}. A lattice that achieves the generalized capacity of the AWGN channel without restrictions, also achieves the channel capacity of the power constrained AWGN channel, with a properly chosen spherical shaping region (see also [12]).

In the rest of this work we shall concentrate on the lattice design and the lattice decoding algorithm, and not on the shaping region or shaping algorithms. We shall use lattices with d​e​t​(𝑮)=1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑮1det(\boldsymbol{G})=1, where analysis and simulations will be carried for the AWGN channel without restrictions. A capacity achieving lattice will have small error probability for noise variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} which is close to the theoretical limit 12​π​e12𝜋𝑒\frac{1}{2\pi e}.

II-B Syndrome and Parity Check Matrix for Lattice Codes

A binary (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k) error correcting code is defined by its n×k𝑛𝑘n\times k binary generator matrix 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G}. A binary information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} with dimension k𝑘k is encoded by x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where calculations are performed in the finite field GF(2). The parity check matrix 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is an (n−k)×n𝑛𝑘𝑛(n-k)\times n matrix such that x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is a codeword if and only if 𝑯​x¯=0¯𝑯¯𝑥¯0\boldsymbol{H}\underline{x}=\underline{0}. The input to the decoder is the noisy codeword y¯=x¯+e¯¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑒\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{e}, where e¯¯𝑒\underline{e} is the error sequence and addition is done in the finite field. The decoder typically starts by calculating the syndrome s¯=𝑯​y¯=𝑯​(x¯+e¯)=𝑯​e¯¯𝑠𝑯¯𝑦𝑯¯𝑥¯𝑒𝑯¯𝑒\underline{s}=\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}=\boldsymbol{H}(\underline{x}+\underline{e})=\boldsymbol{H}\underline{e} which depends only on the noise sequence and not on the transmitted codeword.

We would now like to extend the definitions of the parity check matrix and the syndrome to lattice codes. An n𝑛n-dimensional lattice code is defined by its n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n lattice generator matrix 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} (throughout this paper we assume that 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} is square, but the results are easily extended to the non-square case). Every codeword is of the form x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} is a vector of integers. Therefore, 𝑮−1​x¯superscript𝑮1¯𝑥\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}\underline{x} is a vector of integers for every codeword x¯¯𝑥\underline{x}. We define the parity check matrix for the lattice code as 𝑯=Δ𝑮−1superscriptΔ𝑯superscript𝑮1\boldsymbol{H}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}. Given a noisy codeword y¯=x¯+w¯¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑤\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{w} (where w𝑤w is the additive noise vector, e.g. AWGN, added by real arithmetic), we can then define the syndrome as s¯=Δf​r​a​c​{𝑯​y¯}superscriptΔ¯𝑠𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑯¯𝑦\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}\}, where f​r​a​c​{x}𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑥frac\{x\} is the fractional part of x𝑥x, defined as frac{x}=x−⌊x⌉frac\{x\}=x-\left\lfloor x\right\rceil, where ⌊x⌉delimited-⌊⌉𝑥\left\lfloor x\right\rceil denotes the nearest integer to x𝑥x. The syndrome s¯¯𝑠\underline{s} will be zero if and only if y¯¯𝑦\underline{y} is a lattice point, since 𝑯​y¯𝑯¯𝑦\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y} will then be a vector of integers with zero fractional part. For a noisy codeword, the syndrome will equal s¯=f​r​a​c​{𝑯​y¯}=f​r​a​c​{𝑯​(x¯+w¯)}=f​r​a​c​{𝑯​w¯}¯𝑠𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑯¯𝑦𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑯¯𝑥¯𝑤𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑯¯𝑤\underline{s}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}\}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}(\underline{x}+\underline{w})\}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{w}\} and therefore will depend only on the noise sequence and not on the transmitted codeword, as desired.

Note that the above definitions of the syndrome and parity check matrix for lattice codes are consistent with the definitions of the dual lattice and the dual code[19]: the dual lattice of a lattice 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} is defined as the lattice with generator matrix 𝑯=𝑮−1𝑯superscript𝑮1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}, where for binary codes, the dual code of 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} is defined as the code whose generator matrix is 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, the parity check matrix of 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G}.

II-C Low Density Lattice Codes

We shall now turn to the definition of the codes proposed in this paper - low density lattice codes (LDLC).

Definition 1 (LDLC)

An n𝑛n dimensional LDLC is an n𝑛n-dimensional lattice code with a non-singular lattice generator matrix 𝐆𝐆\boldsymbol{G} satisfying |d​e​t​(𝐆)|=1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝐆1|det(\boldsymbol{G})|=1, for which the parity check matrix 𝐇=𝐆−1𝐇superscript𝐆1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1} is sparse. The i𝑖i’th row degree risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, i=1,2,…​n𝑖12…𝑛i=1,2,...n is defined as the number of nonzero elements in row i𝑖i of 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H}, and the i𝑖i’th column degree cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}, i=1,2,…​n𝑖12…𝑛i=1,2,...n is defined as the number of nonzero elements in column i𝑖i of 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H}.

Note that in binary LDPC codes, the code is completely defined by the locations of the nonzero elements of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}. In LDLC there is another degree of freedom since we also have to choose the values of the nonzero elements of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}.

Definition 2 (regular LDLC)

An n𝑛n dimensional LDLC is regular if all the row degrees and column degrees of the parity check matrix are equal to a common degree d𝑑d.

Definition 3 (magic square LDLC)

An n𝑛n dimensional regular LDLC with degree d𝑑d is called “magic square LDLC” if every row and column of the parity check matrix 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H} has the same d𝑑d nonzero values, except for a possible change of order and random signs. The sorted sequence of these d𝑑d values h1≥h2≥…≥hd>0subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑑0h_{1}\geq h_{2}\geq...\geq h_{d}>0 will be referred to as the generating sequence of the magic square LDLC.

For example, the matrix

𝐇=(0−0.80−0.5100.80010−0.500.5100.8000−0.5−0.80110000.50.80.5−1−0.8000)𝐇00.800.5100.800100.500.5100.80000.50.80110000.50.80.510.8000\mathbf{\boldsymbol{H}}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cccccc}0&-0.8&0&-0.5&1&0\\ 0.8&0&0&1&0&-0.5\\ 0&0.5&1&0&0.8&0\\ 0&0&-0.5&-0.8&0&1\\ 1&0&0&0&0.5&0.8\\ 0.5&-1&-0.8&0&0&0\end{array}\right)

is a parity check matrix of a magic square LDLC with lattice dimension n=6𝑛6n=6, degree d=3𝑑3d=3 and generating sequence {1,0.8,0.5}10.80.5\{1,0.8,0.5\}. This 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} should be further normalized by the constant |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|} in order to have |d​e​t​(𝑯)|=|d​e​t​(𝑮)|=1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑮1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=|det(\boldsymbol{G})|=1, as required by Definition 1.

The bipartite graph of an LDLC is defined similarly to LDPC codes: it is a graph with variable nodes at one side and check nodes at the other side. Each variable node corresponds to a single element of the codeword x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Each check node corresponds to a check equation (a row of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}). A check equation is of the form ∑khk​xik=i​n​t​e​g​e​rsubscript𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑥subscript𝑖𝑘𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑔𝑒𝑟\sum_{k}h_{k}x_{i_{k}}=integer, where iksubscript𝑖𝑘i_{k} denotes the locations of the nonzero elements at the appropriate row of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} are the values of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} at these locations and the integer at the right hand side is unknown. An edge connects check node i𝑖i and variable node j𝑗j if and only if Hi,j≠0subscript𝐻𝑖𝑗0H_{i,j}\neq 0. This edge is assigned the value Hi,jsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑗H_{i,j}. Figure 1 illustrates the bi-partite graph of a magic square LDLC with degree 3. In the figure, every variable node xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} is also associated with its noisy channel observation yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}.

Finally, a k𝑘k-loop is defined as a loop in the bipartite graph that consists of k𝑘k edges. A bipartite graph, in general, can only contain loops with even length. Also, a 2-loop, which consists of two parallel edges that originate from the same variable node to the same check node, is not possible by the definition of the graph. However, longer loops are certainly possible. For example, a 4-loop exists when two variable nodes are both connected to the same pair of check nodes.

III Iterative Decoding for the AWGN Channel

Assume that the codeword x¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b} was transmitted, where b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} is a vector of integers. We observe the noisy codeword y¯=x¯+w¯¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑤\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{w}, where w¯¯𝑤\underline{w} is a vector of i.i.d Gaussian noise samples with common variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, and we need to estimate the integer valued vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. The maximum likelihood (ML) estimator is then b¯^=arg​minb¯‖y¯−𝑮​b¯‖2^¯𝑏subscript¯𝑏superscriptnorm¯𝑦𝑮¯𝑏2\hat{\underline{b}}=\arg\mathop{\min}\limits_{\underline{b}}||\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}||^{2}.

Our decoder will not estimate directly the integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. Instead, it will estimate the probability density function (PDF) of the codeword vector x¯¯𝑥\underline{x}. Furthermore, instead of calculating the n𝑛n-dimensional PDF of the whole vector x¯¯𝑥\underline{x}, we shall calculate the n𝑛n one-dimensional PDF’s for each of the components xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} of this vector (conditioned on the whole observation vector y¯¯𝑦\underline{y}). In appendix A it is shown that fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) is a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions:

fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯)=C⋅∑l¯∈𝑮∩Bδ​(xk−lk)⋅e−d2​(l¯,y¯)/2​σ2subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦⋅𝐶subscript¯𝑙𝑮𝐵⋅𝛿subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑙𝑘superscript𝑒superscript𝑑2¯𝑙¯𝑦2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y})=C\cdot\sum_{\underline{l}\in\boldsymbol{G}\cap B}\delta(x_{k}-l_{k})\cdot e^{-d^{2}(\underline{l},\underline{y})/2\sigma^{2}} (1)

where l¯¯𝑙\underline{l} is a lattice point (vector), lksubscript𝑙𝑘l_{k} is its k𝑘k-th component, C𝐶C is a constant independent of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} and d​(l¯,y¯)𝑑¯𝑙¯𝑦d(\underline{l},\underline{y}) is the Euclidean distance between l¯¯𝑙\underline{l} and y¯¯𝑦\underline{y}. Direct evaluation of (1) is not practical, so our decoder will try to estimate fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) (or at least approximate it) in an iterative manner.

Our decoder will decode to the infinite lattice, thus ignoring the shaping region boundaries. This approximate decoding method is no longer exact maximum likelihood decoding, and is usually denoted “lattice decoding” [12].

The calculation of fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) is involved since the components xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} are not independent random variables (RV’s), because x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is restricted to be a lattice point. Following [5] we use a “trick” - we assume that the xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}’s are independent, but add a condition that assures that x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is a lattice point. Specifically, define s¯=Δ𝑯⋅x¯superscriptΔ¯𝑠⋅𝑯¯𝑥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. Restricting x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} to be a lattice point is equivalent to restricting s¯∈ℤn¯𝑠superscriptℤ𝑛\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}. Therefore, instead of calculating fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) under the assumption that x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is a lattice point, we can calculate fxk|y¯​(xk|y¯,s¯∈ℤn)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑦¯𝑠superscriptℤ𝑛f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}) and assume that the xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) with a continuous PDF (that does not include Dirac delta functions). It still remains to set fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}), the PDF of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}. Under the i.i.d assumption, the PDF of the codeword x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is fx¯​(x¯)=∏k=1nfxk​(xk)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}). As shown in Appendix B, the value of fx¯​(x¯)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) is not important at values of x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} which are not lattice points, but at a lattice point it should be proportional to the probability of using this lattice point. Since we assume that all lattice points are used equally likely, fx¯​(x¯)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) must have the same value at all lattice points. A reasonable choice for fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) is then to use a uniform distribution such that x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} will be uniformly distributed in an n𝑛n-dimensional cube. For an exact ML decoder (that takes into account the boundaries of the shaping region), it is enough to choose the range of fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) such that this cube will contain the shaping region. For our decoder, that performs lattice decoding, we should set the range of fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) large enough such that the resulting cube will include all the lattice points which are likely to be decoded. The derivation of the iterative decoder shows that this range can be set as large as needed without affecting the complexity of the decoder.

The derivation in [5] further imposed the tree assumption. In order to understand the tree assumption, it is useful to define the tier diagram, which is shown in Figure 2 for a regular LDLC with degree 3. Each vertical line corresponds to a check equation. The tier 1 nodes of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} are all the elements xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} that take place in a check equation with x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}. The tier 2 nodes of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} are all the elements that take place in check equations with the tier 1 elements of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}, and so on. The tree assumption assumes that all the tree elements are distinct (i.e. no element appears in different tiers or twice in the same tier). This assumption simplifies the derivation, but in general, does not hold in practice, so our iterative algorithm is not guaranteed to converge to the exact solution (1) (see Section IV).

The detailed derivation of the iterative decoder (using the above “trick” and the tree assumption) is given in Appendix C. In Section III-A below we present the final resulting algorithm. This iterative algorithm can also be explained by intuitive arguments, described after the algorithm specification.

III-A The Iterative Decoding Algorithm

The iterative algorithm is most conveniently represented by using a message passing scheme over the bipartite graph of the code, similarly to LDPC codes. The basic difference is that in LDPC codes the messages are scalar values (e.g. the log likelihood ratio of a bit), where for LDLC the messages are real functions over the interval (−∞,∞)(-\infty,\infty). As in LDPC, in each iteration the check nodes send messages to the variable nodes along the edges of the bipartite graph and vice versa. The messages sent by the check nodes are periodic extensions of PDF’s. The messages sent by the variable nodes are PDF’s.

LDLC iterative decoding algorithm:

Denote the variable nodes by x1,x2,…,xnsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n} and the check nodes by c1,c2,…​cnsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑛c_{1},c_{2},...c_{n}.

  • •

    Initialization: each variable node xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} sends to all its check nodes the message fk(0)​(x)=12​π​σ2​e−(yk−x)22​σ2superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘0𝑥12𝜋superscript𝜎2superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑥22superscript𝜎2f_{k}^{(0)}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}.

  • •

    Basic iteration - check node message: Each check node sends a (different) message to each of the variable nodes that are connected to it. For a specific check node denote (without loss of generality) the appropriate check equation by ∑l=1rhl​xml=i​n​t​e​g​e​rsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑟subscriptℎ𝑙subscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑔𝑒𝑟\sum_{l=1}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}=integer, where xmlsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑙x_{m_{l}}, l=1,2​…​r𝑙12…𝑟l=1,2...r are the variable nodes that are connected to this check node (and r𝑟r is the appropriate row degree of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}). Denote by fl​(x)subscript𝑓𝑙𝑥f_{l}(x), l=1,2​…​r𝑙12…𝑟l=1,2...r, the message that was sent to this check node by variable node xmlsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑙x_{m_{l}} in the previous half-iteration. The message that the check node transmits back to variable node xmjsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗x_{m_{j}} is calculated in three basic steps.

    1. 1.

      The convolution step - all messages, except fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x), are convolved (after expanding each fl​(x)subscript𝑓𝑙𝑥f_{l}(x) by hlsubscriptℎ𝑙h_{l}):

      p~j(x)=f1(xh1)⊛⋯fj−1(xhj−1)⊛\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{j}(x)=f_{1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{1}}\right)\circledast\cdots f_{j-1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{j-1}}\right)\circledast
      ⊛fj+1​(xhj+1)⊛⋯​⋯⊛fr​(xhr)⊛absent⊛⊛subscript𝑓𝑗1𝑥subscriptℎ𝑗1⋯⋯subscript𝑓𝑟𝑥subscriptℎ𝑟\displaystyle\circledast f_{j+1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{j+1}}\right)\circledast\cdots\cdots\circledast f_{r}\left(\frac{x}{h_{r}}\right) (2)
    2. 2.

    3. 3.

      The periodic extension step - The result is extended to a periodic function with period 1/|hj|1subscriptℎ𝑗1/|h_{j}|:

      Qj​(x)=∑i=−∞∞pj​(x−ihj)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗𝑥𝑖subscriptℎ𝑗\displaystyle Q_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}p_{j}\left(x-\frac{i}{h_{j}}\right) (3)

    The function Qj​(x)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥Q_{j}(x) is the message that is finally sent to variable node xmjsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗x_{m_{j}}.

  • •

    Basic iteration - variable node message: Each variable node sends a (different) message to each of the check nodes that are connected to it. For a specific variable node xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, assume that it is connected to check nodes cm1,cm2,…​cmesubscript𝑐subscript𝑚1subscript𝑐subscript𝑚2…subscript𝑐subscript𝑚𝑒c_{m_{1}},c_{m_{2}},...c_{m_{e}}, where e𝑒e is the appropriate column degree of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}. Denote by Ql​(x)subscript𝑄𝑙𝑥Q_{l}(x), l=1,2,…​e𝑙12…𝑒l=1,2,...e, the message that was sent from check node cmlsubscript𝑐subscript𝑚𝑙c_{m_{l}} to this variable node in the previous half-iteration. The message that is sent back to check node cmjsubscript𝑐subscript𝑚𝑗c_{m_{j}} is calculated in two basic steps:

    1. 1.

      The product step: f~j​(x)=e−(yk−x)22​σ2​∏l=1l≠jeQl​(x)subscript~𝑓𝑗𝑥superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑥22superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙1𝑙𝑗𝑒subscript𝑄𝑙𝑥\tilde{f}_{j}(x)=e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq j\end{subarray}}^{e}Q_{l}(x)

      The normalization step: fj​(x)=f~j​(x)∫−∞∞f~j​(x)​𝑑xsubscript𝑓𝑗𝑥subscript~𝑓𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝑓𝑗𝑥differential-d𝑥f_{j}(x)=\frac{\tilde{f}_{j}(x)}{\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{f}_{j}(x)dx}

    This basic iteration is repeated for the desired number of iterations.

  • •

    Final decision: After finishing the iterations, we want to estimate the integer information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. First, we estimate the final PDF’s of the codeword elements xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, k=1,2,…​n𝑘12…𝑛k=1,2,...n, by calculating the variable node messages at the last iteration without omitting any check node message in the product step: f~f​i​n​a​l(k)​(x)=e−(yk−x)22​σ2​∏l=1eQl​(x)subscriptsuperscript~𝑓𝑘𝑓𝑖𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑥superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑥22superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙1𝑒subscript𝑄𝑙𝑥\tilde{f}^{(k)}_{final}(x)=e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{l=1}^{e}Q_{l}(x). Then, we estimate each xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} by finding the peak of its PDF: xk^=a​r​g​maxx⁡f~f​i​n​a​l(k)​(x)^subscript𝑥𝑘𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript~𝑓𝑘𝑓𝑖𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑥\hat{x_{k}}=arg\max_{x}\tilde{f}^{(k)}_{final}(x). Finally, we estimate b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} as b¯^=⌊𝑯x¯^⌉\underline{\hat{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\underline{\hat{x}}\right\rceil.

The operation of the iterative algorithm can be intuitively explained as follows. The check node operation is equivalent to calculating the PDF of xmjsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗x_{m_{j}} from the PDF’s of xmisubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑖x_{m_{i}}, i=1,2,…,j−1,j+1,…​r𝑖12…𝑗1𝑗1…𝑟i=1,2,...,j-1,j+1,...r, given that ∑l=1rhl​xml=i​n​t​e​g​e​rsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑟subscriptℎ𝑙subscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑔𝑒𝑟\sum_{l=1}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}=integer, and assuming that xmisubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑖x_{m_{i}} are independent. Extracting xmjsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗x_{m_{j}} from the check equation, we get xmj=1hj​(i​n​t​e​g​e​r−∑l=1l≠jrhl​xml)subscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗1subscriptℎ𝑗𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑔𝑒𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑙𝑗𝑟subscriptℎ𝑙subscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑙x_{m_{j}}=\frac{1}{h_{j}}(integer-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq j\end{subarray}}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}). Since the PDF of a sum of independent random variables is the convolution of the corresponding PDF’s, equation (1) and the stretching step that follows it simply calculate the PDF of xmjsubscript𝑥subscript𝑚𝑗x_{m_{j}}, assuming that the integer at the right hand side of the check equation is zero. The result is then periodically extended such that a properly shifted copy exists for every possible value of this (unknown) integer. The variable node gets such a message from all the check equations that involve the corresponding variable. The check node messages and the channel PDF are treated as independent sources of information on the variable, so they are multiplied all together.

Note that the periodic extension step at the check nodes is equivalent to a convolution with an infinite impulse train. With this observation, the operation of the variable nodes is completely analogous to that of the check nodes: the variable nodes multiply the incoming messages by the channel PDF, where the check nodes convolve the incoming messages with an impulse train, which can be regarded as a generalized “integer PDF”.

In the above formulation, the integer information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} is recovered from the PDF’s of the codeword elements xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}. An alternative approach is to calculate the PDF of each integer element bmsubscript𝑏𝑚b_{m} directly as the PDF of the left hand side of the appropriate check equation. Using the tree assumption, this can be done by simply calculating the convolution p~​(x)~𝑝𝑥\tilde{p}(x) as in (1), but this time without omitting any PDF, i.e. all the received variable node messages are convolved. Then, the integer bmsubscript𝑏𝑚b_{m} is determined by b^m=a​r​g​maxj∈ℤ⁡p~​(j)subscript^𝑏𝑚𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑗ℤ~𝑝𝑗\hat{b}_{m}=arg\max_{j\in\mathbb{Z}}\tilde{p}(j).

Figure 3 shows an example for a regular LDLC with degree d=5𝑑5d=5. The figure shows all the signals that are involved in generating a variable node message for a certain variable node. The top signal is the channel Gaussian, centered around the noisy observation of the variable. The next 4 signals are the periodically extended PDF’s that arrived from the check nodes, and the bottom signal is the product of all the 5 signals. It can be seen that each periodic signal has a different period, according to the relevant coefficient of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}. Also, the signals with larger period have larger variance. This diversity resolves all the ambiguities such that the multiplication result (bottom plot) remains with a single peak. We expect the iterative algorithm to converge to a solution where a single peak will remain at each PDF, located at the desired value and narrow enough to estimate the information.

IV Convergence

IV-A The Gaussian Mixture Model

Interestingly, for LDLC we can come up with a convergence analysis that in many respects is more specific than the similar analysis for LDPC.

We start by introducing basic claims about Gaussian PDF’s. Denote Gm,V​(x)=12​π​V​e−(x−m)22​Vsubscript𝐺𝑚𝑉𝑥12𝜋𝑉superscript𝑒superscript𝑥𝑚22𝑉G_{m,V}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi V}}e^{-\frac{(x-m)^{2}}{2V}}.

Claim 1 (convolution of Gaussians)

The convolution of n𝑛n Gaussians with mean values m1,m2,…,mnsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…subscript𝑚𝑛m_{1},m_{2},...,m_{n} and variances V1,V2,…,Vnsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2…subscript𝑉𝑛V_{1},V_{2},...,V_{n}, respectively, is a Gaussian with mean m1+m2+…+mnsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…subscript𝑚𝑛m_{1}+m_{2}+...+m_{n} and variance V1+V2+…+Vnsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2…subscript𝑉𝑛V_{1}+V_{2}+...+V_{n}.

Proof:

See [21]. ∎

Claim 2 (product of n𝑛n Gaussians)

Let Gm1,V1​(x)subscript𝐺subscript𝑚1subscript𝑉1𝑥G_{m_{1},V_{1}}(x), Gm2,V2​(x)subscript𝐺subscript𝑚2subscript𝑉2𝑥G_{m_{2},V_{2}}(x),…,Gmn,Vn​(x)subscript𝐺subscript𝑚𝑛subscript𝑉𝑛𝑥G_{m_{n},V_{n}}(x) be n𝑛n Gaussians with mean values m1,m2,…,mnsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…subscript𝑚𝑛m_{1},m_{2},...,m_{n} and variances V1,V2,…,Vnsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2…subscript𝑉𝑛V_{1},V_{2},...,V_{n} respectively. Then, the product of these Gaussians is a scaled Gaussian: ∏i=1nGmi,Vi​(x)=A^⋅Gm^,V^​(x)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐺subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖𝑥⋅^𝐴subscript𝐺^𝑚^𝑉𝑥\prod_{i=1}^{n}G_{m_{i},V_{i}}(x)=\hat{A}\cdot G_{\hat{m},\hat{V}}(x), where 1V^=∑i=1n1Vi1^𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝑉𝑖\frac{1}{\hat{V}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{V_{i}}, m^=∑i=1nmi​Vi−1∑i=1nVi−1^𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖1\hat{m}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}V_{i}^{-1}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}V_{i}^{-1}}, and A^=1(2​π)n−1​V^−1​∏k=1nVk⋅e−V^2​∑i=1n∑j=i+1n(mi−mj)2Vi⋅Vj^𝐴⋅1superscript2𝜋𝑛1superscript^𝑉1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑉𝑘superscript𝑒^𝑉2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚𝑗2⋅subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑗\hat{A}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(2\pi)^{n-1}\hat{V}^{-1}\prod_{k=1}^{n}V_{k}}}\cdot e^{-\frac{\hat{V}}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=i+1}^{n}\frac{(m_{i}-m_{j})^{2}}{V_{i}\cdot V_{j}}}.

Proof:

By straightforward mathematical manipulations. ∎

The reason that we are interested in the properties of Gaussian PDF’s lies in the following lemma.

Lemma 1

Each message that is exchanged between the check nodes and variable nodes in the LDLC decoding algorithm (i.e. Qj​(x)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥Q_{j}(x) and fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x)), at every iteration, can be expressed as a Gaussian mixture of the form M​(x)=∑j=1∞Aj​Gmj,Vj​(x)𝑀𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝐺subscript𝑚𝑗subscript𝑉𝑗𝑥M(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}A_{j}G_{m_{j},V_{j}}(x).

Proof:

By induction: The initial messages are Gaussians, and the basic operations of the iterative decoder preserve the Gaussian mixture nature of Gaussian mixture inputs (convolution and multiplication preserve the Gaussian nature according to claims 1 and 2, stretching, expanding and shifting preserve it by the definition of a Gaussian, and periodic extension transforms a single Gaussian to a mixture and a mixture to a mixture). ∎

Convergence analysis should therefore analyze the convergence of the variances, mean values and amplitudes of the Gaussians in each mixture.

IV-B Convergence of the Variances

We shall now analyze the behavior of the variances, and start with the following lemma.

Lemma 2

For both variable node messages and check node messages, all the Gaussians that take place in the same mixture have the same variance.

Proof:

By induction. The initial variable node messages are single element mixtures so the claim obviously holds. Assume now that all the variable node messages at iteration t𝑡t are mixtures where all the Gaussians that take place in the same mixture have the same variance. In the convolution step (1), each variable node message is first expanded. All Gaussians in the expanded mixture will still have the same variance, since the whole mixture is expanded together. Then, d−1𝑑1d-1 expanded Gaussian mixtures are convolved. In the resulting mixture, each Gaussian will be the result of convolving d−1𝑑1d-1 single Gaussians, one from each mixture. According to claim 1, all the Gaussians in the convolution result will have the same variance, which will equal the sum of the d−1𝑑1d-1 variances of the expanded messages. The stretching and periodic extension (3) do not change the equal variance property, so it holds for the final check node messages. The variable nodes multiply d−1𝑑1d-1 check node messages. Each Gaussian in the resulting mixture is a product of d−1𝑑1d-1 single Gaussians, one from each mixture, and the channel noise Gaussian. According to claim 2, they will all have the same variance. The final normalization step does not change the variances so the equal variance property is kept for the final variable node messages at iteration t+1𝑡1t+1. ∎

Until this point we did not impose any restrictions on the LDLC. From now on, we shall restrict ourselves to magic square regular LDLC (see Definition 3). The basic iterative equations that relate the variances at iteration t+1𝑡1t+1 to the variances at iteration t𝑡t are summarized in the following two lemmas.

Lemma 3

For magic square LDLC, variable node messages that are sent at the same iteration along edges with the same absolute value have the same variance.

Proof:

See Appendix D. ∎

Lemma 4

For magic square LDLC with degree d𝑑d, denote the variance of the messages that are sent at iteration t𝑡t along edges with weight ±hlplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑙\pm h_{l} by Vl(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑙V^{(t)}_{l}. The variance values V1(t),V2(t),…,Vd(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡2…subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑑V^{(t)}_{1},V^{(t)}_{2},...,V^{(t)}_{d} obey the following recursion:

1Vi(t+1)=1σ2+∑m=1m≠idhm2∑j=1j≠mdhj2​Vj(t)1subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1𝑖1superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑚𝑖𝑑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑗𝑚𝑑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑗2subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑗\displaystyle\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}m=1\\ m\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{h_{m}^{2}}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq m\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{j}^{2}V^{(t)}_{j}} (4)

Proof:

See Appendix D. ∎

If α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1, the variances may still converge, but convergence rate may be as slow as o​(1/t)𝑜1𝑡o(1/t), as illustrated in Appendix D.

Convergence of the variances to zero implies that the Gaussians approach impulses. This is a desired property of the decoder, since the exact PDF that we want to calculate is indeed a weighted sum of impulses (see (1)). It can be seen that by designing a code with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, i.e. h12>∑i=2dhi2superscriptsubscriptℎ12superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖2h_{1}^{2}>\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}, one variance approaches a constant (and not zero). However, all the other variances approach zero, where all variances converge in an exponential rate. This will be the preferred mode because the information can be recovered even if a single variance does not decay to zero, where exponential convergence is certainly preferred over slow 1/t1𝑡1/t convergence. Therefore, from now on we shall restrict our analysis to magic square LDLC with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1.

Theorem 1 shows that every iteration, each variable node will generate d−1𝑑1d-1 messages with variances that approach zero, and a single message with variance that approaches a constant. The message with nonzero variance will be transmitted along the edge with largest weight (i.e. h1subscriptℎ1h_{1}). However, from the derivation of Appendix D it can be seen that the opposite happens for the check nodes: each check node will generate d−1𝑑1d-1 messages with variances that approach a constant, and a single message with variance that approaches zero. The check node message with zero approaching variance will be transmitted along the edge with largest weight.

IV-C Convergence of the Mean Values

The reason that the messages are mixtures and not single Gaussians lies in the periodic extension step (3) at the check nodes, and every Gaussian at the output of this step can be related to a single index of the infinite sum. Therefore, we can label each Gaussian at iteration t𝑡t with a list of all the indices that were used in (3) during its creation process in iterations 1,2,…​t12…𝑡1,2,...t.

Definition 4 (label of a Gaussian)

The label of a Gaussian consists of a sequence of triplets of the form {t,c,i}𝑡𝑐𝑖\{t,c,i\}, where t𝑡t is an iteration index, c𝑐c is a check node index and i𝑖i is an integer. The labels are initialized to the empty sequence. Then, the labels are updated along each iteration according to the following update rules:

  1. 1.

    In the periodic extension step (3), each Gaussian in the output periodic mixture is assigned the label of the specific Gaussian of pj​(x)subscript𝑝𝑗𝑥p_{j}(x) that generated it, concatenated with a single triplet {t,c,i}𝑡𝑐𝑖\{t,c,i\}, where t𝑡t is the current iteration index, c𝑐c is the check node index and i𝑖i is the index in the infinite sum of (3) that corresponds to this Gaussian.

  2. 2.

    In the convolution step and the product step, each Gaussian in the output mixture is assigned a label that equals the concatenation of all the labels of the specific Gaussians in the input messages that formed this Gaussian.

  3. 3.

    The stretching and normalization steps do not alter the label of each Gaussian: Each Gaussian in the stretched/normalized mixture inherits the label of the appropriate Gaussian in the original mixture.

Definition 5 (a consistent Gaussian)

A Gaussian in a mixture is called “[tasubscript𝑡𝑎t_{a}, tbsubscript𝑡𝑏t_{b}] consistent” if its label contains no contradictions for iterations tasubscript𝑡𝑎t_{a} to tbsubscript𝑡𝑏t_{b}, i.e. for every pair of triplets {t1,c1,i1}subscript𝑡1subscript𝑐1subscript𝑖1\{t_{1},c_{1},i_{1}\}, {t2,c2,i2}subscript𝑡2subscript𝑐2subscript𝑖2\{t_{2},c_{2},i_{2}\} such that ta≤t1,t2≤tbformulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑎subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2subscript𝑡𝑏t_{a}\leq t_{1},t_{2}\leq t_{b}, if c1=c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1}=c_{2} then i1=i2subscript𝑖1subscript𝑖2i_{1}=i_{2}. A [00, ∞\infty] consistent Gaussian will be simply called a consistent Gaussian.

We can relate every consistent Gaussian to a unique integer vector b¯∈ℤn¯𝑏superscriptℤ𝑛\underline{b}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}, which holds the n𝑛n integers used in the n𝑛n check nodes. Since in the periodic extension step (3) the sum is taken over all integers, a consistent Gaussian exists in each variable node message for every possible integer valued vector b¯∈ℤn¯𝑏superscriptℤ𝑛\underline{b}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}. We shall see later that this consistent Gaussian corresponds to the lattice point 𝑮​b¯𝑮¯𝑏\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}.

According to Theorem 1, if we choose the nonzero values of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} such that α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, every variable node generates d−1𝑑1d-1 messages with variances approaching zero and a single message with variance that approaches a constant. We shall refer to these messages as “narrow” messages and “wide” messages, respectively. For a given integer valued vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, we shall concentrate on the consistent Gaussians that relate to b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} in all the n​d𝑛𝑑nd variable node messages that are generated in each iteration (a single Gaussian in each message). The following lemmas summarize the asymptotic behavior of the mean values of these consistent Gaussians for the narrow messages.

Lemma 5

For a magic square LDLC with degree d𝑑d and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, consider the d−1𝑑1d-1 narrow messages that are sent from a specific variable node. Consider further a single Gaussian in each message, which is the consistent Gaussian that relates to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. Asymptotically, the mean values of these d−1𝑑1d-1 Gaussians become equal.

Proof:

See Appendix E. ∎

Lemma 6

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d𝑑d and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, consider only consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} and belong to narrow messages. Denote the common mean value of the d−1𝑑1d-1 such Gaussians that are sent from variable node i𝑖i at iteration t𝑡t by mi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡𝑖m^{(t)}_{i}, and arrange all these mean values in a column vector m¯(t)superscript¯𝑚𝑡\underline{m}^{(t)} of dimension n𝑛n. Define the error vector e¯(t)=Δm¯(t)−x¯superscriptΔsuperscript¯𝑒𝑡superscript¯𝑚𝑡¯𝑥\underline{e}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{m}^{(t)}-\underline{x}, where x¯=𝐆​b¯¯𝑥𝐆¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b} is the lattice point that corresponds to b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. Then, for large t𝑡t, e¯(t)superscript¯𝑒𝑡\underline{e}^{(t)} satisfies:

e¯(t+1)≈−𝑯~⋅e¯(t)superscript¯𝑒𝑡1⋅~𝑯superscript¯𝑒𝑡\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}\approx-\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)} (6)

where 𝐇~~𝐇\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is derived from 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H} by permuting the rows such that the ±h1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ1\pm h_{1} elements will be placed on the diagonal, dividing each row by the appropriate diagonal element (h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} or −h1subscriptℎ1-h_{1}), and then nullifying the diagonal.

Proof:

See Appendix E. ∎

We can now state the following theorem, which describes the conditions for convergence and the steady state value of the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the narrow variable node messages.

Theorem 2

For a magic square LDLC with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the narrow variable node messages that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} are assured to converge if and only if all the eigenvalues of 𝐇~~𝐇\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} have magnitude less than 111, where 𝐇~~𝐇\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Lemma 6. When this condition is fulfilled, the mean values converge to the coordinates of the appropriate lattice point: m¯(∞)=𝐆⋅b¯superscript¯𝑚⋅𝐆¯𝑏\underline{m}^{(\infty)}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}.

Proof:

Immediate from Lemma 6. ∎

Note that without adding random signs to the LDLC nonzero values, the all-ones vector will be an eigenvector of 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} with eigenvalue ∑i=2dhih1superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑑subscriptℎ𝑖subscriptℎ1\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}}{h_{1}}, which may exceed 111.

Interestingly, recursion (6) is also obeyed by the error of the Jacobi method for solving systems of sparse linear equations [22] (see also Section VIII-A), when it is used to solve 𝑯​m¯=b¯𝑯¯𝑚¯𝑏\boldsymbol{H}\underline{m}=\underline{b} (with solution m¯=𝑮​b¯¯𝑚𝑮¯𝑏\underline{m}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}). Therefore, the LDLC decoder can be viewed as a superposition of Jacobi solvers, one for each possible value of the integer valued vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}.

We shall now turn to the convergence of the mean values of the wide messages. The asymptotic behavior is summarized in the following lemma.

Lemma 7

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, consider only consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} and belong to wide messages. Denote the mean value of such a Gaussian that is sent from variable node i𝑖i at iteration t𝑡t by mi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡𝑖m^{(t)}_{i}, and arrange all these mean values in a column vector m¯(t)superscript¯𝑚𝑡\underline{m}^{(t)} of dimension n𝑛n. Define the error vector e¯(t)=Δm¯(t)−𝐆​b¯superscriptΔsuperscript¯𝑒𝑡superscript¯𝑚𝑡𝐆¯𝑏\underline{e}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{m}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Then, for large t𝑡t, e¯(t)superscript¯𝑒𝑡\underline{e}^{(t)} satisfies:

e¯(t+1)≈−𝑭⋅e¯(t)+(1−α)​(y¯−𝑮​b¯)superscript¯𝑒𝑡1⋅𝑭superscript¯𝑒𝑡1𝛼¯𝑦𝑮¯𝑏\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}\approx-\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)}+(1-\alpha)(\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}) (7)

where y¯¯𝑦\underline{y} is the noisy codeword and 𝐅𝐅\boldsymbol{F} is an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n matrix defined by:

Fk,l={Hr,kHr,lif ​k≠l​ and there exist a row ​r​ of Hfor which ​|Hr,l|=h1​ and ​Hr,k≠00otherwisesubscript𝐹𝑘𝑙casessubscript𝐻𝑟𝑘subscript𝐻𝑟𝑙if 𝑘𝑙 and there exist a row 𝑟 of Hmissing-subexpressionfor which subscript𝐻𝑟𝑙subscriptℎ1 and subscript𝐻𝑟𝑘00otherwise\displaystyle F_{k,l}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{H_{r,k}}{H_{r,l}}&\textrm{if }k\neq l\textrm{ and there exist a row }r\textrm{ of H}\\ &\textrm{for which }|H_{r,l}|=h_{1}\textrm{ and }H_{r,k}\neq 0\\ 0&\textrm{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (11)
Proof:

See Appendix E, where an alternative way to construct 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} from 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is also presented. ∎

The conditions for convergence and steady state solution for the wide messages are described in the following theorem.

Theorem 3

For a magic square LDLC with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the wide variable node messages that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} are assured to converge if and only if all the eigenvalues of 𝐅𝐅\boldsymbol{F} have magnitude less than 111, where 𝐅𝐅\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Lemma 7. When this condition is fulfilled, the steady state solution is m¯(∞)=𝐆⋅b¯+(1−α)​(𝐈+𝐅)−1​(y¯−𝐆⋅b¯)superscript¯𝑚⋅𝐆¯𝑏1𝛼superscript𝐈𝐅1¯𝑦⋅𝐆¯𝑏\underline{m}^{(\infty)}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}+(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}(\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}).

Proof:

Immediate from Lemma 7. ∎

Unlike the narrow messages, the mean values of the wide messages do not converge to the appropriate lattice point coordinates. The steady state error depends on the difference between the noisy observation and the lattice point, as well as on α𝛼\alpha, and it decreases to zero as α→1→𝛼1\alpha\rightarrow 1. Note that the final PDF of a variable is generated by multiplying all the d𝑑d check node messages that arrive to the appropriate variable node. d−1𝑑1d-1 of these messages are wide, and therefore their mean values have a steady state error. One message is narrow, so it converges to an impulse at the lattice point coordinate. Therefore, the final product will be an impulse at the correct location, where the wide messages will only affect the magnitude of this impulse. As long as the mean values errors are not too large (relative to the width of the wide messages), this should not cause an impulse that corresponds to a wrong lattice point to have larger amplitude than the correct one. However, for large noise, these steady state errors may cause the decoder to deviate from the ML solution (As explained in Section IV-D).

To summarize the results for the mean values, we considered the mean values of all the consistent Gaussians that correspond to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. A single Gaussian of this form exists in each of the n​d𝑛𝑑nd variable node messages that are generated in each iteration. For each variable node, d−1𝑑1d-1 messages are narrow (have variance that approaches zero) and a single message is wide (variance approaches a constant). Under certain conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of all the narrow messages converge to the appropriate coordinate of the lattice point 𝑮​b¯𝑮¯𝑏\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Under additional conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of the wide messages converge, but the steady state values contain an error term.

We analyzed the behavior of consistent Gaussian. It should be noted that there are many more non-consistent Gaussians. Furthermore non-consistent Gaussians are generated in each iteration for any existing consistent Gaussian. We conjecture that unless a Gaussian is consistent, or becomes consistent along the iterations, it fades out, at least at noise conditions where the algorithm converges. The reason is that non-consistency in the integer values leads to mismatch in the corresponding PDF’s, and so the amplitude of that Gaussian is attenuated.

We considered consistent Gaussians which correspond to a specific integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, but such a set of Gaussians exists for every possible choice of b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, i.e. for every lattice point. Therefore, the narrow messages will converge to a solution that has an impulse at the appropriate coordinate of every lattice point. This resembles the exact solution (1), so the key for proper convergence lies in the amplitudes: we would like the consistent Gaussians of the ML lattice point to have the largest amplitude for each message.

IV-D Convergence of the Amplitudes

We shall now analyze the behavior of the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians (as discussed later, this is not enough for complete convergence analysis, but it certainly gives insight to the nature of the convergence process and its properties). The behavior of the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians is summarized in the following lemma.

Lemma 8

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d𝑑d and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, consider the n​d𝑛𝑑nd consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration t𝑡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,…​n​d𝑖12…𝑛𝑑i=1,2,...nd, and define the log-amplitude as li(t)=log⁡pi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑙𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖l^{(t)}_{i}=\log p^{(t)}_{i}. Arrange these n​d𝑛𝑑nd log-amplitudes in a column vector l¯(t)superscript¯𝑙𝑡\underline{l}^{(t)}, such that element (k−1)​d+i𝑘1𝑑𝑖(k-1)d+i corresponds to the message that is sent from variable node k𝑘k along an edge with weight ±hiplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑖\pm h_{i}. Assume further that the bipartite graph of the LDLC contains no 4-loops. Then, the log-amplitudes satisfy the following recursion:

l¯(t+1)=𝑨⋅l¯(t)−a¯(t)−c¯(t)superscript¯𝑙𝑡1⋅𝑨superscript¯𝑙𝑡superscript¯𝑎𝑡superscript¯𝑐𝑡\displaystyle\underline{l}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{A}\cdot\underline{l}^{(t)}-\underline{a}^{(t)}-\underline{c}^{(t)} (12)

with initialization l¯(0)=0¯superscript¯𝑙0¯0\underline{l}^{(0)}=\underline{0}. 𝐀𝐀\boldsymbol{A} is an n​d×n​d𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑑nd\times nd matrix which is all zeros except exactly (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} ’111’s in each row and each column. The element of the excitation vector a¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡\underline{a}^{(t)} at location (k−1)​d+i𝑘1𝑑𝑖(k-1)d+i (where k=1,2,…​n𝑘12…𝑛k=1,2,...n and i=1,2,…​d𝑖12…𝑑i=1,2,...d) equals:

a(k−1)​d+i(t)=subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑘1𝑑𝑖absent\displaystyle a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}= (13)
=V^k,i(t)2​(∑l=1l≠id∑j=l+1j≠id(m~k,l(t)−m~k,j(t))2V~k,l(t)⋅V~k,j(t)+∑l=1l≠id(m~k,l(t)−yk)2σ2⋅V~k,l(t))absentsubscriptsuperscript^𝑉𝑡𝑘𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑙𝑖𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑙1𝑗𝑖𝑑superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑘𝑗2⋅subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑙𝑖𝑑superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑘𝑙subscript𝑦𝑘2⋅superscript𝜎2subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑘𝑙\displaystyle=\frac{\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}}{2}\left(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=l+1\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,l}-\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,j}\right)^{2}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l}\cdot\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,l}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\sigma^{2}\cdot\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l}}\right)
