Finally, c¯(t)superscript¯𝑐𝑡\underline{c}^{(t)} is a constant excitation term that is independent of the integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} (i.e. is the same for all consistent Gaussians). Note that an iteration is defined as sending variable node messages, followed by sending check node messages. The first iteration (where the variable nodes send the initialization PDF) is regarded as iteration 00.

Proof:

At the check node, the amplitude of a Gaussian at the convolution output is the product of the amplitudes of the corresponding Gaussians in the appropriate variable node messages. At the variable node, the amplitude of a Gaussian at the product output is the product of the amplitudes of the corresponding Gaussians in the appropriate check node messages, multiplied by the Gaussian scaling term, according to claim 2. Since we assume that the bipartite graph of the LDLC contains no 4-loops, an amplitude of a variable node message at iteration t𝑡t will therefore equal the product of (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} amplitudes of Gaussians of variable node messages from iteration t−1𝑡1t-1, multiplied by the Gaussian scaling term. This proves (12) and shows that A𝐴A has (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} ’1’s in every row. However, since each variable node message affects exactly (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} variable node messages of the next iteration, A𝐴A must also have (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} ’1’s in every column. The total excitation term −a¯(t)−c¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡superscript¯𝑐𝑡-\underline{a}^{(t)}-\underline{c}^{(t)} corresponds to the logarithm of the Gaussian scaling term. Each element of this scaling term results from the product of d−1𝑑1d-1 check node Gaussians and the channel Gaussian, according to claim 2. This scaling term sums over all the pairs of Gaussians, and in (13) the sum is separated to pairs that include the channel Gaussian and pairs that do not. The total excitation is divided between (13), which depends on the choice of the integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, and c¯(t)superscript¯𝑐𝑡\underline{c}^{(t)}, which includes all the constant terms that are independent on b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} (including the normalization operation which is performed at the variable node). ∎

Since there are exactly (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2} ’111’s in each column of the matrix 𝑨𝑨\boldsymbol{A}, it is easy to see that the all-ones vector is an eigenvector of 𝑨𝑨\boldsymbol{A}, with eigenvalue (d−1)2superscript𝑑12(d-1)^{2}. If d>2𝑑2d>2, this eigenvalue is larger than 111, meaning that the recursion (12) is non-stable.

It can be seen that the excitation term a¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡\underline{a}^{(t)} has two components. The first term sums the squared differences between the mean values of all the possible pairs of received check node messages (weighted by the inverse product of the appropriate variances). It therefore measures the mismatch between the incoming messages. This mismatch will be small if the mean values of the consistent Gaussians converge to the coordinates of a lattice point (any lattice point). The second term sums the squared differences between the mean values of the incoming messages and the noisy channel output yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}. This term measures the mismatch between the incoming messages and the channel measurement. It will be smallest if the mean values of the consistent Gaussians converge to the coordinates of the ML lattice point.

The following lemma summarizes some properties of the excitation term a¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡\underline{a}^{(t)}.

Lemma 9

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d𝑑d, α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the consistent Gaussians that correspond to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. According to Lemma 8, their amplitudes satisfy recursion (12). The excitation term a¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡\underline{a}^{(t)} of (12), which is defined by (13), satisfies the following properties:

  1. 1.

    ai(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖a^{(t)}_{i}, the i𝑖i’th element of a¯(t)superscript¯𝑎𝑡\underline{a}^{(t)}, is non-negative, finite and bounded for every i𝑖i and every t𝑡t. Moreover, ai(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖a^{(t)}_{i} converges to a finite non-negative steady state value as t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\infty.

  2. 2.

    limt→∞∑i=1n​dai(t)=12​σ2​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)subscript→𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖12superscript𝜎2superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i}=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where y¯¯𝑦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword and 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} is a positive definite matrix defined by:

    𝑾=Δ(d+1−α)​𝑰−2​(1−α)​(𝑰+𝑭)−1+superscriptΔ𝑾𝑑1𝛼𝑰limit-from21𝛼superscript𝑰𝑭1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{W}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(d+1-\alpha)\boldsymbol{I}-2(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}+ (14)
    +(1−α)​(𝑰+𝑭)−1T​((d−1)2​𝑰−𝑭T​𝑭)​(𝑰+𝑭)−11𝛼superscript𝑰𝑭superscript1𝑇superscript𝑑12𝑰superscript𝑭𝑇𝑭superscript𝑰𝑭1\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{{-1}^{T}}\left((d-1)^{2}\boldsymbol{I}-\boldsymbol{F}^{T}\boldsymbol{F}\right)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}

    where 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Lemma 7.

  3. 3.

    For an LDLC with degree d>2𝑑2d>2, the weighted infinite sum ∑j=0∞∑i=1n​dai(j)(d−1)2​j+2superscriptsubscript𝑗0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖superscript𝑑12𝑗2\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}} converges to a finite value.

Proof:

See Appendix F. ∎

The following theorem addresses the question of which consistent Gaussian will have the maximal asymptotic amplitude. We shall first consider the case of an LDLC with degree d>2𝑑2d>2, and then consider the special case of d=2𝑑2d=2 in a separate theorem.

Theorem 4

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d>2𝑑2d>2, α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the n​d𝑛𝑑nd consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration t𝑡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,…​n​d𝑖12…𝑛𝑑i=1,2,...nd, and define the product-of-amplitudes as P(t)=Δ∏i=1n​dpi(t)superscriptΔsuperscript𝑃𝑡superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖P^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\prod_{i=1}^{nd}p^{(t)}_{i}. Define further S=∑j=0∞∑i=1n​dai(j)(d−1)2​j+2𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑗0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖superscript𝑑12𝑗2S=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}}, where ai(j)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖a^{(j)}_{i} is defined by (13) (S𝑆S is well defined according to Lemma 9). Then:

  1. 1.

    The integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} for which the consistent Gaussians will have the largest asymptotic product-of-amplitudes limt→∞P(t)subscript→𝑡superscript𝑃𝑡\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}P^{(t)} is the one for which S𝑆S is minimized.

  2. 2.

    The product-of-amplitudes for the consistent Gaussians that correspond to all other integer vectors will decay to zero in a super-exponential rate.

Proof:

As in Lemma 8, define the log-amplitudes li(t)=Δlog⁡pi(t)superscriptΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑙𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖l^{(t)}_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\log p^{(t)}_{i}. Define further s(t)=Δ∑i=1n​dli(t)superscriptΔsuperscript𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑙𝑡𝑖s^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}l^{(t)}_{i}. Taking the element-wise sum of (12), we get:

s(t+1)=(d−1)2​s(t)−∑i=1n​dai(t)superscript𝑠𝑡1superscript𝑑12superscript𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖\displaystyle s^{(t+1)}=(d-1)^{2}s^{(t)}-\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} (15)

with initialization s(0)=0superscript𝑠00s^{(0)}=0. Note that we ignored the term ∑i=1n​dci(t)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{nd}c^{(t)}_{i}. As shown below, we are looking for the vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that maximizes s(t)superscript𝑠𝑡s^{(t)}. Since (15) is a linear difference equation, and the term ∑i=1n​dci(t)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{nd}c^{(t)}_{i} is independent of b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, its effect on s(t)superscript𝑠𝑡s^{(t)} is common to all b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} and is therefore not interesting.

Define now s~(t)=Δs(t)(d−1)2​tsuperscriptΔsuperscript~𝑠𝑡superscript𝑠𝑡superscript𝑑12𝑡\tilde{s}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{s^{(t)}}{(d-1)^{2t}}. Substituting in (15), we get:

s~(t+1)=s~(t)−1(d−1)2​t+2​∑i=1n​dai(t)superscript~𝑠𝑡1superscript~𝑠𝑡1superscript𝑑12𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{s}^{(t+1)}=\tilde{s}^{(t)}-\frac{1}{(d-1)^{2t+2}}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} (16)

with initialization s~(0)=0superscript~𝑠00\tilde{s}^{(0)}=0, which can be solved to get:

s~(t)=−∑j=0t−1∑i=1n​dai(j)(d−1)2​j+2superscript~𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖superscript𝑑12𝑗2\displaystyle\tilde{s}^{(t)}=-\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}} (17)

We would now like to compare the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians with various values of the corresponding integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} in order to find the lattice point whose consistent Gaussians will have largest product-of-amplitudes. From the definitions of s(t)superscript𝑠𝑡s^{(t)} and s~(t)superscript~𝑠𝑡\tilde{s}^{(t)} we then have:

P(t)=es(t)=e(d−1)2​t⋅s~(t)superscript𝑃𝑡superscript𝑒superscript𝑠𝑡superscript𝑒⋅superscript𝑑12𝑡superscript~𝑠𝑡\displaystyle P^{(t)}=e^{s^{(t)}}=e^{(d-1)^{2t}\cdot\tilde{s}^{(t)}} (18)

Consider two integer vectors b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that relate to two lattice points. Denote the corresponding product-of-amplitudes by P0(t)superscriptsubscript𝑃0𝑡P_{0}^{(t)} and P1(t)superscriptsubscript𝑃1𝑡P_{1}^{(t)}, respectively, and assume that for these two vectors S𝑆S converges to the values S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} and S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}, respectively. Then, taking into account that limt→∞s~(t)=−Ssubscript→𝑡superscript~𝑠𝑡𝑆\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\tilde{s}^{(t)}=-S, the asymptotic ratio of the product-of-amplitudes for these lattice points will be:

limt→∞P1(t)P0(t)=e−(d−1)2​t⋅S1e−(d−1)2​t⋅S0=e(d−1)2​t⋅(S0−S1)subscript→𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃0𝑡superscript𝑒⋅superscript𝑑12𝑡subscript𝑆1superscript𝑒⋅superscript𝑑12𝑡subscript𝑆0superscript𝑒⋅superscript𝑑12𝑡subscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{P_{1}^{(t)}}{P_{0}^{(t)}}=\frac{e^{-(d-1)^{2t}\cdot S_{1}}}{e^{-(d-1)^{2t}\cdot S_{0}}}=e^{(d-1)^{2t}\cdot(S_{0}-S_{1})} (19)

It can be seen that if S0<S1subscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1S_{0}<S_{1}, the ratio decreases to zero in a super exponential rate. This shows that the lattice point for which S𝑆S is minimized will have the largest product-of-amplitudes, where for all other lattice points, the product-of-amplitudes will decay to zero in a super-exponential rate (recall that the normalization operation at the variable node keeps the sum of all amplitudes in a message to be 1). This completes the proof of the theorem. ∎

We now have to find which integer valued vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} minimizes S𝑆S. The analysis is difficult because the weighting factor inside the sum of (17) performs exponential weighting of the excitation terms, where the dominant terms are those of the first iterations. Therefore, we can not use the asymptotic results of Lemma 9, but have to analyze the transient behavior. However, the analysis is simpler for the case of an LDLC with row and column degree of d=2𝑑2d=2, so we shall first turn to this simple case (note that for this case, both the convolution in the check nodes and the product at the variable nodes involve only a single message).

Theorem 5

For a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d=2𝑑2d=2, α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the 2​n2𝑛2n consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration t𝑡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,…​2​n𝑖12…2𝑛i=1,2,...2n, and define the product-of-amplitudes as P(t)=Δ∏i=12​npi(t)superscriptΔsuperscript𝑃𝑡superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖12𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖P^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\prod_{i=1}^{2n}p^{(t)}_{i}. Then:

  1. 1.

    The integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} for which the consistent Gaussians will have the largest asymptotic product-of-amplitudes limt→∞P(t)subscript→𝑡superscript𝑃𝑡\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}P^{(t)} is the one for which (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) is minimized, where 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} is defined by (14) and y¯¯𝑦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword.

  2. 2.

    The product-of-amplitudes for the consistent Gaussians that correspond to all other integer vectors will decay to zero in an exponential rate.

Proof:

For d=2𝑑2d=2 (15) becomes:

s(t+1)=s(t)−∑i=12​nai(t)superscript𝑠𝑡1superscript𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖12𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖\displaystyle s^{(t+1)}=s^{(t)}-\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(t)}_{i} (20)

With solution:

s(t)=−∑j=0t−1∑i=12​nai(j)superscript𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖12𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖\displaystyle s^{(t)}=-\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i} (21)

Denote Sa=limj→∞∑i=12​nai(j)subscript𝑆𝑎subscript→𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖12𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖S_{a}=\lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i}. Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a} is well defined according to Lemma 9. For large t𝑡t, we then have s(t)≈−t⋅Sasuperscript𝑠𝑡⋅𝑡subscript𝑆𝑎s^{(t)}\approx-t\cdot S_{a}. Therefore, for two lattice points with excitation sum terms which approach Sa​0,Sa​1subscript𝑆𝑎0subscript𝑆𝑎1S_{a0},S_{a1}, respectively, the ratio of the corresponding product-of-amplitudes will approach

limt→∞P1(t)P0(t)=e−Sa​1⋅te−Sa​0⋅t=e(Sa​0−Sa​1)⋅tsubscript→𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃0𝑡superscript𝑒⋅subscript𝑆𝑎1𝑡superscript𝑒⋅subscript𝑆𝑎0𝑡superscript𝑒⋅subscript𝑆𝑎0subscript𝑆𝑎1𝑡\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{P_{1}^{(t)}}{P_{0}^{(t)}}=\frac{e^{-S_{a1}\cdot t}}{e^{-S_{a0}\cdot t}}=e^{(S_{a0}-S_{a1})\cdot t} (22)

If Sa​0<Sa​1subscript𝑆𝑎0subscript𝑆𝑎1S_{a0}<S_{a1}, the ratio decreases to zero exponentially (unlike the case of d>2𝑑2d>2 where the rate was super-exponential, as in (19)). This shows that the lattice point for which Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a} is minimized will have the largest product-of-amplitudes, where for all other lattice points, the product-of-amplitudes will decay to zero in an exponential rate (recall that the normalization operation at the variable node keeps the sum of all amplitudes in a message to be 1). This completes the proof of the second part of the theorem.

We still have to find the vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that minimizes Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a}. The basic difference between the case of d=2𝑑2d=2 and the case of d>2𝑑2d>2 is that for d>2𝑑2d>2 we need to analyze the transient behavior of the excitation terms, where for d=2𝑑2d=2 we only need to analyze the asymptotic behavior, which is much easier to handle.

According to Lemma 9, we have:

Sa=Δlimj→∞∑i=12​nai(j)=12​σ2​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscriptΔsubscript𝑆𝑎subscript→𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖12𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑗𝑖12superscript𝜎2superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦\displaystyle S_{a}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i}=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) (23)

where 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} is defined by (14) and y¯¯𝑦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword. Therefore, for d=2𝑑2d=2, the lattice points whose consistent Gaussians will have largest product-of-amplitudes is the point for which (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) is minimized. This completes the proof of the theorem. ∎

For d=2𝑑2d=2 we could find an explicit expression for the “winning” lattice point. As discussed above, we could not find an explicit expression for d>2𝑑2d>2, since the result depends on the transient behavior of the excitation sum term, and not only on the steady state value. However, a reasonable conjecture is to assume that b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that maximizes the steady state excitation will also maximize the term that depends on the transient behavior. This means that a reasonable conjecture is to assume that the “winning” lattice point for d>2𝑑2d>2 will also minimize an expression of the form (23).

Note that for d>2𝑑2d>2 we can still show that for “weak” noise, the ML point will have the minimal S𝑆S. To see that, it comes out from (13) that for zero noise, the ML lattice point will have ai(t)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖0a^{(t)}_{i}=0 for every t𝑡t and i𝑖i, where all other lattice points will have ai(t)>0subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖0a^{(t)}_{i}>0 for at least some i𝑖i and t𝑡t. Therefore, the ML point will have a minimal excitation term along the transient behavior so it will surely have the minimal S𝑆S and the best product-of-amplitudes. As the noise increases, it is difficult to analyze the transient behavior of ai(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖a^{(t)}_{i}, as discussed above.

Note that the ML solution minimizes (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where the above analysis yields minimization of (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}). Obviously, for zero noise (i.e. y¯=𝑮⋅b¯¯𝑦⋅𝑮¯𝑏\underline{y}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\ \underline{b}) both minimizations will give the correct solution with zero score. As the noise increases, the solutions may deviate from one another. Therefore, both minimizations will give the same solution for “weak” noise but may give different solutions for “strong” noise.

An example for another decoder that performs this form of minimization is the linear detector, which calculates b¯^=⌊𝑯⋅y¯⌉\hat{\underline{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{y}\right\rceil (where ⌊x⌉delimited-⌊⌉𝑥\left\lfloor x\right\rceil denotes the nearest integer to x𝑥x). This is equivalent to minimizing (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) with 𝑾=𝑯T​𝑯=𝑮−1T​𝑮−1𝑾superscript𝑯𝑇𝑯superscript𝑮superscript1𝑇superscript𝑮1\boldsymbol{W}=\boldsymbol{H}^{T}\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{{-1}^{T}}\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}. The linear detector fails to yield the ML solution if the noise is too strong, due to its inherent noise amplification.

For the LDLC iterative decoder, we would like that the deviation from the ML decoder due to the 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} matrix would be negligible in the expected range of noise variance. Experimental results (see Section IX) show that the iterative decoder indeed converges to the ML solution for noise variance values that approach channel capacity. However, for quantization or shaping applications (see Section VIII-B), where the effective noise is uniformly distributed along the Voronoi cell of the lattice (and is much stronger than the noise variance at channel capacity) the iterative decoder fails, and this can be explained by the influence of the 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} matrix on the minimization, as described above. Note from (14) that as α→1→𝛼1\alpha\rightarrow 1, 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} approaches a scaled identity matrix, which means that the minimization criterion approaches the ML criterion. However, the variances converge as αtsuperscript𝛼𝑡\alpha^{t}, so as α→1→𝛼1\alpha\rightarrow 1 convergence time approaches infinity.

Until this point, we concentrated only on consistent Gaussians, and checked what lattice point maximizes the product-of-amplitudes of all the corresponding consistent Gaussians. However, this approach does not necessarily lead to the lattice point that will be finally chosen by the decoder, due to 3 main reasons:

  1. 1.

    It comes out experimentally that the strongest Gaussian in each message is not necessarily a consistent Gaussian, but a Gaussian that started as non-consistent and became consistent at a certain iteration. Such a Gaussian will finally converge to the appropriate lattice point, since the convergence of the mean values is independent of initial conditions. The non-consistency at the first several iterations, where the mean values are still very noisy, allows these Gaussians to accumulate stronger amplitudes than the consistent Gaussians (recall that the exponential weighting in (17) for d>2𝑑2d>2 results in strong dependency on the behavior at the first iterations).

  2. 2.

    There is an exponential number of Gaussians that start as non-consistent and become consistent (with the same integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}) at a certain iteration, and the final amplitude of the Gaussians at the lattice point coordinates will be determined by the sum of all these Gaussians.

  3. 3.

    We ignored non-consistent Gaussians that endlessly remain non-consistent. We have not shown it analytically, but it is reasonable to assume that the excitation terms for such Gaussians will be weaker than for Gaussians that become consistent at some point, so their amplitude will fade away to zero. However, non-consistent Gaussians are born every iteration, even at steady state. The “newly-born” non-consistent Gaussians may appear as sidelobes to the main impulse, since it may take several iterations until they are attenuated. Proper choice of the coefficients of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} may minimize this effect, as discussed in Sections III-A and V-A. However, these Gaussians may be a problem for small d𝑑d (e.g. d=2𝑑2d=2) where the product step at the variable node does not include enough messages to suppress them.

Note that the first two issues are not a problem for d=2𝑑2d=2, where the winning lattice point depends only on the asymptotic behavior. The amplitude of a sum of Gaussians that converged to the same coordinates will still be governed by (21) and the winning lattice point will still minimize (23). The third issue is a problem for small d𝑑d, but less problematic for large d𝑑d, as described above.

As a result, we can not regard the convergence analysis of the consistent Gaussians’ amplitudes as a complete convergence analysis. However, it can certainly be used as a qualitative analysis that gives certain insights to the convergence process. Two main observations are:

  1. 1.

    The narrow variable node messages tend to converge to single impulses at the coordinates of a single lattice point. This results from (19), (22), which show that the “non-winning” consistent Gaussians will have amplitudes that decrease to zero relative to the amplitude of the “winning” consistent Gaussian. This result remains valid for the sum of non-consistent Gaussians that became consistent at a certain point, because it results from the non-stable nature of the recursion (12), which makes strong Gaussians stronger in an exponential manner. The single impulse might be accompanied by weak “sidelobes” due to newly-born non-consistent Gaussians.

    Interestingly, this form of solution is different from the exact solution (1), where every lattice point is represented by an impulse at the appropriate coordinate, with amplitude that depends on the Euclidean distance of the lattice point from the observation. The iterative decoder’s solution has a single impulse that corresponds to a single lattice point, where all other impulses have amplitudes that decay to zero. This should not be a problem, as long as the ML point is the remaining point (see discussion above).

  2. 2.

    We have shown that for d=2𝑑2d=2 the strongest consistent Gaussians relate to b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that minimizes an expression of the form (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}). We proposed a conjecture that this is also true for d>2𝑑2d>2. We can further widen the conjecture to say that the finally decoded b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} (and not only the b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that relates to strongest consistent Gaussians) minimizes such an expression. Such a conjecture can explain why the iterative decoder works well for decoding near channel capacity, but fails for quantization or shaping, where the effective noise variance is much larger.

IV-E Summary of Convergence Results

To summarize the convergence analysis, it was first shown that the variable node messages are Gaussian mixtures. Therefore, it is sufficient to analyze the sequences of variances, mean values and relative amplitudes of the Gaussians in each mixture. Starting with the variances, it was shown that with proper choice of the magic square LDLC generating sequence, each variable node generates d−1𝑑1d-1 “narrow” messages, whose variance decreases exponentially to zero, and a single “wide” message, whose variance reaches a finite value. Consistent Gaussians were then defined as Gaussians that their generation process always involved the same integer at the same check node. Consistent Gaussians can then be related to an integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} or equivalently to the lattice point 𝑮​b¯𝑮¯𝑏\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. It was then shown that under appropriate conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of consistent Gaussians that belong to narrow messages converge to the coordinates of the appropriate lattice point. The mean values of wide messages also converge to these coordinates, but with a steady state error. Then, the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians were analyzed. For d=2𝑑2d=2 it was shown that the consistent Gaussians with maximal product-of-amplitudes (over all messages) are those that correspond to an integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} than minimizes (𝑮​b¯−y¯)T​𝑾​(𝑮​b¯−y¯)superscript𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦𝑇𝑾𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where 𝑾𝑾\boldsymbol{W} is a positive definite matrix that depends only on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}. The product-of-amplitudes for all other consistent Gaussians decays to zero. For d>2𝑑2d>2 the analysis is complex and depends on the transient behavior of the mean values and variances (and not only on their steady state values), but a reasonable conjecture is to assume that a same form of criterion is also minimized for d>2𝑑2d>2. The result is different from the ML lattice point, which minimizes ‖𝑮⋅b¯−y¯‖2superscriptnorm⋅𝑮¯𝑏¯𝑦2\left\|\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}-\underline{y}\right\|^{2}, where both criteria give the same point for weak noise but may give different solutions for strong noise. This may explain the experiments where the iterative decoder is successful in decoding the ML point for the AWGN channel near channel capacity, but fails in quantization or shaping applications where the effective noise is much stronger. These results also show that the iterative decoder converges to impulses at the coordinates of a single lattice point. It was then explained that analyzing the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians is not sufficient, so these results can not be regarded as a complete convergence analysis. However, the analysis gave a set of necessary conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, and also led to useful insights to the convergence process.

V Code Design

V-A Choosing the Generating Sequence

We shall concentrate on magic square LDLC, since they have inherent diversity of the nonzero elements in each row and column, which was shown above to be beneficial. It still remains to choose the LDLC generating sequence h1,h2,…​hdsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑑h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}. Assume that the algorithm converged, and each PDF has a peak at the desired value. When the periodic functions are multiplied at a variable node, the correct peaks will then align. We would like that all the other peaks will be strongly attenuated, i.e. there will be no other point where the peaks align. This resembles the definition of the least common multiple (LCM) of integers: if the periods were integers, we would like to have their LCM as large as possible. This argument suggests the sequence {1/2,1/3,1/5,1/7,1/11,1/13,1/17,…}12131517111113117…\{1/2,1/3,1/5,1/7,1/11,1/13,1/17,...\}, i.e. the reciprocals of the smallest d𝑑d prime numbers. Since the periods are 1/h1,1/h2,…​1/hd1subscriptℎ11subscriptℎ2…1subscriptℎ𝑑1/h_{1},1/h_{2},...1/h_{d}, we will get the desired property. Simulations have shown that increasing d𝑑d beyond 777 with this choice gave negligible improvement. Also, performance was improved by adding some “dither” to the sequence, resulting in {1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55}12.3113.1715.1117.33111.71113.11117.55\{1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55\}. For d<7𝑑7d<7, the first d𝑑d elements are used.

An alternative approach is a sequence of the form {1,ϵ,ϵ,…,ϵ}1italic-ϵitalic-ϵ…italic-ϵ\{1,\epsilon,\epsilon,...,\epsilon\}, where ϵ<<1much-less-thanitalic-ϵ1\epsilon<<1. For this case, every variable node will receive a single message with period 111 and d−1𝑑1d-1 messages with period 1/ϵ1italic-ϵ1/\epsilon. For small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the period of these d−1𝑑1d-1 messages will be large and multiplication by the channel Gaussian will attenuate all the unwanted replicas. The single remaining replica will attenuate all the unwanted replicas of the message with period 1. A convenient choice is ϵ=1ditalic-ϵ1𝑑\epsilon=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}, which ensures that α=d−1d<1𝛼𝑑1𝑑1\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}<1, as required by Theorem 1. As an example, for d=7𝑑7d=7 the sequence will be {1,17,17,17,17,17,17}1171717171717\{1,\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}}\}.

V-B Necessary Conditions on 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H}

The magic square LDLC definition and convergence analysis imply four necessary conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}:

  1. 1.

    |d​e​t​(𝑯)|=1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=1. This condition is part of the LDLC definition, which ensures proper density of the lattice points in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m}. If |d​e​t​(𝑯)|≠1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|\neq 1, it can be easily normalized by dividing 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} by |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}. Note that practically we can allow |d​e​t​(𝑯)|≠1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|\neq 1 as long as |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n≈1𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}\approx 1, since |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|} is the gain factor of the transmitted codeword. For example, if n=1000𝑛1000n=1000, having |d​e​t​(𝑯)|=0.01𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯0.01|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=0.01 is acceptable, since we have |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n=0.995𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯0.995\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}=0.995, which means that the codeword has to be further amplified by 20⋅log10⁡(0.995)=0.04⋅20subscript100.9950.0420\cdot\log_{10}(0.995)=0.04 dB, which is negligible.

    Note that normalizing 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is applicable only if 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is non-singular. If 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is singular, a row and a column should be sequentially omitted until 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} becomes full rank. This process may result in slightly reducing n𝑛n and a slightly different row and column degrees than originally planned.

  2. 2.

    α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, where α=Δ∑i=2dhi2h12superscriptΔ𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖2superscriptsubscriptℎ12\alpha\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}. This guarantees exponential convergence rate for the variances (Theorem 1). Choosing a smaller α𝛼\alpha results in faster convergence, but we should not take α𝛼\alpha too small since the steady state variance of the wide variable node messages, as well as the steady state error of the mean values of these messages, increases when α𝛼\alpha decreases, as discussed in Section IV-C. This may result in deviation of the decoded codeword from the ML codeword, as discussed in Section IV-D. For the first LDLC generating sequence of the previous subsection, we have α=0.92𝛼0.92\alpha=0.92 and 0.870.870.87 for d=7𝑑7d=7 and 555, respectively, which is a reasonable trade off. For the second sequence type we have α=d−1d𝛼𝑑1𝑑\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}.

  3. 3.

    All the eigenvalues of 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} must have magnitude less than 111, where 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Theorem 2. This is a necessary condition for convergence of the mean values of the narrow messages. Note that adding random signs to the nonzero 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} elements is essential to fulfill this necessary condition, as explained in Section IV-C.

  4. 4.

    All the eigenvalues of 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} must have magnitude less than 111, where 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Theorem 3. This is a necessary condition for convergence of the mean values of the wide messages.

Interestingly, it comes out experimentally that for large codeword length n𝑛n and relatively small degree d𝑑d (e.g. n≥1000𝑛1000n\geq 1000 and d≤10𝑑10d\leq 10), a magic square LDLC with generating sequence that satisfies h1=1subscriptℎ11h_{1}=1 and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 results in 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} that satisfies all these four conditions: 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} is nonsingular without any need to omit rows and columns, |d​e​t​(𝑯)|n≈1𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}\approx 1 without any need for normalization, and all eigenvalues of 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} and 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} have magnitude less than 1 (typically, the largest eigenvalue of 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} or 𝑭𝑭\boldsymbol{F} has magnitude of 0.94−0.970.940.970.94-0.97, almost independently of n𝑛n and the choice of nonzero 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} locations). Therefore, by simply dividing the first generating sequence of the previous subsection by its first element, the constructed 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} meets all the necessary conditions, where the second type of sequence meets the conditions without any need for modifications.

V-C Construction of 𝐇𝐇\boldsymbol{H} for Magic Square LDLC

We shall now present a simple algorithm for constructing a parity check matrix for a magic square LDLC. If we look at the bipartite graph, each variable node and each check node has d𝑑d edges connected to it, one with every possible weight h1,h2,…​hdsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑑h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}. All the edges that have the same weight hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} form a permutation from the variable nodes to the check nodes (or vice versa). The proposed algorithm generates d𝑑d random permutations and then searches sequentially and cyclically for 2-loops (two parallel edges from a variable node to a check node) and 4-loops (two variable nodes that both are connected to a pair of check nodes). When such a loop is found, a pair is swapped in one of the permutations such that the loop is removed. A detailed pseudo-code for this algorithm is given in Appendix G.

VI Decoder Implementation

Each PDF should be approximated with a discrete vector with resolution ΔΔ\Delta and finite range. According to the Gaussian Q-function, choosing a range of, say, 6​σ6𝜎6\sigma to both sides of the noisy channel observation will ensure that the error probability due to PDF truncation will be ≈10−9absentsuperscript109\approx 10^{-9}. Near capacity, σ2≈12​π​esuperscript𝜎212𝜋𝑒\sigma^{2}\approx\frac{1}{2\pi e}, so 12​σ≈312𝜎312\sigma\approx 3. Simulation showed that resolution errors became negligible for Δ=1/64Δ164\Delta=1/64. Each PDF was then stored in a L=256𝐿256L=256 elements vector, corresponding to a range of size 444.

At the check node, the PDF fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x) that arrives from variable node j𝑗j is first expanded by hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} (the appropriate coefficient of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}) to get fj​(x/hj)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥subscriptℎ𝑗f_{j}(x/h_{j}). In a discrete implementation with resolution ΔΔ\Delta the PDF is a vector of values fj​(k​Δ)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑘Δf_{j}(k\Delta), k∈ℤ𝑘ℤk\in\mathbb{Z}. As described in Section V, we shall usually use hj≤1subscriptℎ𝑗1h_{j}\leq 1 so the expanded PDF will be shorter than the original PDF. If the expand factor 1/|hj|1subscriptℎ𝑗1/|h_{j}| was an integer, we could simply decimate fj​(k​Δ)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑘Δf_{j}(k\Delta) by 1/|hj|1subscriptℎ𝑗1/|h_{j}|. However, in general it is not an integer so we should use some kind of interpolation. The PDF fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x) is certainly not band limited, and as the iterations go on it approaches an impulse, so simple interpolation methods (e.g. linear) are not suitable. Suppose that we need to calculate fj​((k+ϵ)​Δ)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑘italic-ϵΔf_{j}((k+\epsilon)\Delta), where −0.5≤ϵ≤0.50.5italic-ϵ0.5-0.5\leq\epsilon\leq 0.5. A simple interpolation method which showed to be effective is to average fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x) around the desired point, where the averaging window length lwsubscript𝑙𝑤l_{w} is chosen to ensure that every sample of fj​(x)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥f_{j}(x) is used in the interpolation of at least one output point. This ensures that an impulse can not be missed. The interpolation result is then 12​lw+1​∑i=−lwlwfj​((k−i)​Δ)12subscript𝑙𝑤1superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑙𝑤subscript𝑙𝑤subscript𝑓𝑗𝑘𝑖Δ\frac{1}{2l_{w}+1}\sum_{i=-l_{w}}^{l_{w}}f_{j}((k-i)\Delta), where lw=⌊⌈1/|hj|⌉2⌋subscript𝑙𝑤1subscriptℎ𝑗2l_{w}=\left\lfloor\frac{\left\lceil 1/|h_{j}|\right\rceil}{2}\right\rfloor.

The most computationally extensive step at the check nodes is the calculation the convolution of d−1𝑑1d-1 expanded PDF’s. An efficient method is to calculate the fast Fourier transforms (FFTs) of all the PDF’s, multiply the results and then perform inverse FFT (IFFT). The resolution of the FFT should be larger than the expected convolution length, which is roughly Lo​u​t≈L⋅∑i=1dhisubscript𝐿𝑜𝑢𝑡⋅𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptℎ𝑖L_{out}\approx L\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{d}h_{i}, where L𝐿L denotes the original PDF length. Appendix H shows a way to use FFTs of size 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta, where ΔΔ\Delta is the resolution of the PDF. Usually 1/Δ<<Lo​u​tmuch-less-than1Δsubscript𝐿𝑜𝑢𝑡1/\Delta<<L_{out} so FFT complexity is significantly reduced. Practical values are L=256𝐿256L=256 and Δ=1/64Δ164\Delta=1/64, which give an improvement factor of at least 444 in complexity.

Each variable node receives d𝑑d check node messages. The output variable node message is calculated by generating the product of d−1𝑑1d-1 input messages and the channel Gaussian. As the iterations go on, the messages get narrow and may become impulses, with only a single nonzero sample. Quantization effects may cause impulses in two messages to be shifted by one sample. This will result in a zero output (instead of an impulse). Therefore, it was found useful to widen each check node message Q​(k)𝑄𝑘Q(k) prior to multiplication, such that Qw​(k)=∑i=−11Q​(k+i)subscript𝑄𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖11𝑄𝑘𝑖Q_{w}(k)=\sum_{i=-1}^{1}Q(k+i), i.e. the message is added to its right shifted and left shifted (by one sample) versions.

VII Computational Complexity and Storage Requirements

Most of the computational effort is invested in the d𝑑d FFT’s and d𝑑d IFFT’s (of length 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta) that each check node performs each iteration. The total number of multiplications for t𝑡t iterations is o​(n⋅d⋅t⋅1Δ⋅log2⁡(1Δ))𝑜⋅𝑛𝑑𝑡1Δsubscript21Δo\left(n\cdot d\cdot t\cdot\frac{1}{\Delta}\cdot\log_{2}(\frac{1}{\Delta})\right). As in binary LDPC codes, the computational complexity has the attractive property of being linear with block length. However, the constant that precedes the linear term is significantly higher, mainly due to the FFT operations.

The memory requirements are governed by the storage of the n​d𝑛𝑑nd check node and variable node messages, with total memory of o​(n⋅d⋅L)𝑜⋅𝑛𝑑𝐿o(n\cdot d\cdot L). Compared to binary LDPC, the factor of L𝐿L significantly increases the required memory. For example, for n=10,000𝑛10000n=10,000, d=7𝑑7d=7 and L=256𝐿256L=256, the number of storage elements is of the order of 107superscript10710^{7}.

VIII Encoding and Shaping

VIII-A Encoding

The LDLC encoder has to calculate x¯=𝑮⋅b¯¯𝑥⋅𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}, where b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} is an integer message vector. Note that unlike 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H}, 𝑮=𝑯−1𝑮superscript𝑯1\boldsymbol{G}=\boldsymbol{H}^{-1} is not sparse, in general, so the calculation requires computational complexity and storage of o​(n2)𝑜superscript𝑛2o(n^{2}). This is not a desirable property because the decoder’s computational complexity is only o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n). A possible solution is to use the Jacobi method [22] to solve 𝑯⋅x¯=b¯⋅𝑯¯𝑥¯𝑏\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}=\underline{b}, which is a system of sparse linear equations. Using this method, a magic square LDLC encoder calculates several iterations of the form:

x¯(t)=b¯~−𝑯~⋅x¯(t−1)superscript¯𝑥𝑡¯~𝑏⋅~𝑯superscript¯𝑥𝑡1\displaystyle\underline{x}^{(t)}=\underline{\tilde{b}}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}}\cdot\underline{x}^{(t-1)} (24)

with initialization x¯(0)=0¯superscript¯𝑥0¯0\underline{x}^{(0)}=\underline{0}. The matrix 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Lemma 6 of Section IV-C. The vector b¯~¯~𝑏\underline{\tilde{b}} is a permuted and scaled version of the integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, such that the i𝑖i’th element of b¯~¯~𝑏\underline{\tilde{b}} equals the element of b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} for which the appropriate row of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} has its largest magnitude value at the i𝑖i’th location. This element is further divided by this largest magnitude element.

A necessary and sufficient condition for convergence to x¯=𝑮⋅b¯¯𝑥⋅𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b} is that all the eigenvalues of 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} have magnitude less than 111 [22]. However, it was shown that this is also a necessary condition for convergence of the LDLC iterative decoder (see Sections IV-C, V-B), so it is guaranteed to be fulfilled for a properly designed magic square LDLC. Since 𝑯~~𝑯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is sparse, this is an o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n) algorithm, both in complexity and storage.

VIII-B Shaping

For practical use with the power constrained AWGN channel, the encoding operation must be accompanied by shaping, in order to prevent the transmitted codeword’s power from being too large. Therefore, instead of mapping the information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} to the lattice point x¯=𝑮⋅b¯¯𝑥⋅𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}, it should be mapped to some other lattice point x¯′=𝑮⋅b¯′superscript¯𝑥′⋅𝑮superscript¯𝑏′\underline{x}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}^{\prime}, such that the lattice points that are used as codewords belong to a shaping region (e.g. an n𝑛n-dimensional sphere). The shaping operation is the mapping of the integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} to the integer vector b¯′superscript¯𝑏′\underline{b}^{\prime}.

As explained in Section II-A, this work concentrates on the lattice design and the lattice decoding algorithm, and not on the shaping region or shaping algorithms. Therefore, this section will only highlight some basic shaping principles and ideas.

A natural shaping scheme for lattice codes is nested lattice coding [12]. In this scheme, shaping is done by quantizing the lattice point 𝑮⋅b¯⋅𝑮¯𝑏\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b} onto a coarse lattice 𝑮′superscript𝑮′\boldsymbol{G}^{\prime}, where the transmitted codeword is the quantization error, which is uniformly distributed along the Voronoi cell of the coarse lattice. If the second moment of this Voronoi cell is close to that of an n𝑛n-dimensional sphere, the scheme will attain close-to-optimal shaping gain. Specifically, assume that the information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} assumes integer values in the range 0,1,…​M−101…𝑀10,1,...M-1 for some constant integer M𝑀M. Then, we can choose the coarse lattice to be 𝑮′=M​𝑮superscript𝑮bold-′𝑀𝑮\boldsymbol{G^{\prime}}=M\boldsymbol{G}. The volume of the Voronoi cell for this lattice is Mnsuperscript𝑀𝑛M^{n}, since we assume d​e​t​(𝑮)=1𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑮1det(\boldsymbol{G})=1 (see Section II-A). If the shape of the Voronoi cell resembles an n𝑛n-dimensional sphere (as expected from a capacity approaching lattice code), it will attain optimal shaping gain (compared to uncoded transmission of the original integer sequence b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}).

The shaping operation will find the coarse lattice point M​𝑮​k¯𝑀𝑮¯𝑘M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k}, k¯∈ℤn¯𝑘superscriptℤ𝑛\underline{k}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}, which is closest to the fine lattice point x¯=𝑮⋅b¯¯𝑥⋅𝑮¯𝑏\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}. The transmitted codeword will be:

x¯′=x¯−M​𝑮​k¯=𝑮​(b¯−M​k¯)=𝑮​b′¯superscript¯𝑥′¯𝑥𝑀𝑮¯𝑘𝑮¯𝑏𝑀¯𝑘𝑮¯superscript𝑏′\displaystyle\underline{x}^{\prime}=\underline{x}-M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k}=\boldsymbol{G}(\underline{b}-M\underline{k})=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b^{\prime}}

where b¯′=Δb¯−M​k¯superscriptΔsuperscript¯𝑏′¯𝑏𝑀¯𝑘\underline{b}^{\prime}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{b}-M\underline{k} (note that the “inverse shaping” at the decoder, i.e. transforming from b¯′superscript¯𝑏′\underline{b}^{\prime} to b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}, is a simple modulo calculation: b¯=b¯′modM¯𝑏modulosuperscript¯𝑏′𝑀\underline{b}=\underline{b}^{\prime}\mod M). Finding the closest coarse lattice point M​𝑮​k¯𝑀𝑮¯𝑘M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k} to x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is equivalent to finding the closest fine lattice point 𝑮⋅k¯⋅𝑮¯𝑘\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{k} to the vector x¯/M¯𝑥𝑀\underline{x}/M. This is exactly the operation of the iterative LDLC decoder, so we could expect that is could be used for shaping. However, simulations show that the iterative decoding finds a vector k¯¯𝑘\underline{k} with poor shaping gain. The reason is that for shaping, the effective noise is much stronger than for decoding, and the iterative decoder fails to find the nearest lattice point if the noise is too large (see Section IV-D).

Therefore, an alternative algorithm has to be used for finding the nearest coarse lattice point. The complexity of finding the nearest lattice point grows exponentially with the lattice dimension n𝑛n and is not feasible for large dimensions [23]. However, unlike decoding, for shaping applications it is not critical to find the exact nearest lattice point, and approximate algorithms may be considered (see [15]). A possible method [24] is to perform QR decomposition on 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G} in order to transform to a lattice with upper triangular generator matrix, and then use sequential decoding algorithms (such as the Fano algorithm) to search the resulting tree. The main disadvantage of this approach is computational complexity and storage of at least o​(n2)𝑜superscript𝑛2o(n^{2}). Finding an efficient shaping scheme for LDLC is certainly a topic for further research.

IX Simulation Results

Magic square LDLC with the first generating sequence of Section V-A (i.e. {1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55}12.3113.1715.1117.33111.71113.11117.55\{1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55\}) were simulated for the AWGN channel at various block lengths. The degree was d=5𝑑5d=5 for n=100𝑛100n=100 and d=7𝑑7d=7 for all other n𝑛n. For n=100𝑛100n=100 the matrix 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} was further normalized to get d​e​t​(𝑯)n=1𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑡𝑯1\sqrt[n]{det(\boldsymbol{H})}=1. For all other n𝑛n, normalizing the generating sequence such that the largest element has magnitude 111 also gave the desired determinant normalization (see Section V-B). The 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} matrices were generated using the algorithm of Section V-C. PDF resolution was set to Δ=1/256Δ1256\Delta=1/256 with a total range of 444, i.e. each PDF was represented by a vector of L=1024𝐿1024L=1024 elements. High resolution was used since our main target is to prove the LDLC concept and eliminate degradation due to implementation considerations. For this reason, the decoder was used with 200 iterations (though most of the time, a much smaller number was sufficient).

In all simulations the all-zero codeword was used. Approaching channel capacity is equivalent to σ2→12​π​e→superscript𝜎212𝜋𝑒\sigma^{2}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2\pi e} (see Section II-A), so performance is measured in symbol error rate (SER), vs. the distance of the noise variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} from capacity (in dB). The results are shown in Figure 4. At SER of 10−5superscript10510^{-5}, for n=100000𝑛100000n=100000, 100001000010000, 100010001000, 100100100 we can work as close as 0.60.60.6dB, 0.80.80.8dB, 1.51.51.5dB and 3.73.73.7dB from capacity, respectively.

Similar results were obtained for d=7𝑑7d=7 with the second type of generating sequence of Section V-A, i.e. {1,17,17,17,17,17,17}1171717171717\{1,\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}}\}. Results were slightly worse than for the first generating sequence (by less than 0.1 dB). Increasing d𝑑d did not give any visible improvement.

X Conclusion

Low density lattice codes (LDLC) were introduced. LDLC are novel lattice codes that can approach capacity and be decoded efficiently. Good error performance within ∼0.5similar-toabsent0.5\sim 0.5dB from capacity at block length of 100,000 symbols was demonstrated. Convergence analysis was presented for the iterative decoder, which is not complete, but yields necessary conditions on 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} and significant insight to the convergence process. Code parameters were chosen from intuitive arguments, so it is reasonable to assume that when the code structure will be more understood, better parameters could be found, and channel capacity could be approached even closer.

Multi-input, multi-output (MIMO) communication systems have become popular in recent years. Lattice codes have been proposed in this context as space-time codes (LAST) [25]. The concatenation of the lattice encoder and the MIMO channel generates a lattice. If LDLC are used as lattice codes and the MIMO configuration is small, the inverse generator matrix of this concatenated lattice can be assumed to be sparse. Therefore, the MIMO channel and the LDLC can be jointly decoded using an LDLC-like decoder. However, even if a magic square LDLC is used as the lattice code, the concatenated lattice is not guaranteed to be equivalent to a magic square LDLC, and the necessary conditions for convergence are not guaranteed to be fulfilled. Therefore, the usage of LDLC for MIMO systems is a topic for further research.

This finishes the proof of (1). It can be seen that the conditional PDF of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} has a delta function for each lattice point, located at the projection of this lattice point on the coordinate xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, with weight that is proportional to the exponent of the negated squared Euclidean distance of this lattice point from the noisy observation. The ML point will therefore correspond to the delta function with largest weight in each coordinate. Note, however, that if several lattice points have the same projection on a specific coordinate, the weights of the corresponding delta functions will add and may exceed the weight of the ML point.

Appendix B Extending Gallager’s Technique to the Continuous Case

In [5], the derivation of the LDPC iterative decoder was simplified using the following technique: the codeword elements xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} were assumed i.i.d. and a condition was added to all the probability calculations, such that only valid codewords were actually considered. The question is then how to choose the marginal PDF of the codeword elements. In [5], binary codewords were considered, and the i.i.d distribution assumed the values ’0’ and ’1’ with equal probability. Since we extend the technique to the continuous case, we have to set the continuous marginal distribution fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}). It should be set such that fx¯​(x¯)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}), assuming that x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is a lattice point, is the same as f​(x¯|s¯∈ℤn)𝑓conditional¯𝑥¯𝑠superscriptℤ𝑛f(\underline{x}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}), assuming that xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} are i.i.d with marginal PDF fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}), where s¯=Δ𝑯⋅x¯superscriptΔ¯𝑠⋅𝑯¯𝑥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. This fx¯​(x¯)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) equals a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions at all lattice points, where the weight at each lattice point equals the probability to use this point as a codeword.

Before proceeding, we need the following property of conditional probabilities. For any two continuous valued RV’s u𝑢u, v𝑣v we have:

f​(u|v∈{v1,v2,…,vN})=∑k=1Nfu,v​(u,vk)∑k=1Nfv​(vk)𝑓conditional𝑢𝑣subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2…subscript𝑣𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑢𝑣𝑢subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑣subscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle f(u|v\in\{v_{1},v_{2},...,v_{N}\})=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}f_{u,v}(u,v_{k})}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}f_{v}(v_{k})} (27)

(This property can be easily proved by following the lines of [21], pp. 159-160, and can also be extended to the infinite sum case).

Using (27), we now have:

f​(x¯|s¯∈ℤn)=∑i¯∈ℤnfx¯,s¯​(x¯,s¯=i¯)∑i¯∈ℤnfs¯​(i¯)=𝑓conditional¯𝑥¯𝑠superscriptℤ𝑛subscript¯𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑠¯𝑥¯𝑠¯𝑖subscript¯𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛subscript𝑓¯𝑠¯𝑖absent\displaystyle f(\underline{x}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n})=\frac{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f_{\underline{x},\underline{s}}(\underline{x},\underline{s}=\underline{i})}{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f_{\underline{s}}(\underline{i})}=
=C​∑i¯∈ℤnf​(x¯)​f​(s¯=i¯|x¯)=C′​∑i¯∈ℤnf​(x¯)​δ​(x¯−𝑮​i¯)absent𝐶subscript¯𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛𝑓¯𝑥𝑓¯𝑠conditional¯𝑖¯𝑥superscript𝐶′subscript¯𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛𝑓¯𝑥𝛿¯𝑥𝑮¯𝑖\displaystyle=C\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f(\underline{x})f(\underline{s}=\underline{i}|\underline{x})=C^{\prime}\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f(\underline{x})\delta(\underline{x}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{i}) (28)

where C,C′𝐶superscript𝐶′C,C^{\prime} are independent of x¯¯𝑥\underline{x}.

The result is a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions at all lattice points, as desired. Now, the weight at each lattice point should equal the probability to use this point as a codeword. Therefore, fxk​(xk)subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) should be chosen such that at each lattice point, the resulting vector distribution fx¯​(x¯)=∏k=1nfxk​(xk)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) will have a value that is proportional to the probability to use this lattice point. At x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} which is not a lattice point, the value of fx¯​(x¯)subscript𝑓¯𝑥¯𝑥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) is not important.

Appendix C Derivation of the Iterative Decoder

In this appendix we shall derive the LDLC iterative decoder for a code with dimension n𝑛n, using the tree assumption and Gallager’s trick.

Referring to figure 2, assume that there are only 2 tiers. Using Gallager’s trick we assume that the xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}’s are i.i.d. We would like to calculate f(x1|(y¯,s¯∈ℤn)f(x_{1}|(\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}), where s¯=Δ𝑯⋅x¯superscriptΔ¯𝑠⋅𝑯¯𝑥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. Due to the tree assumption, we can do it in two steps:

1. calculate the conditional PDF of the tier 1 variables of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}, conditioned only on the check equations that relate the tier 1 and tier 2 variables.

2. calculate the conditional PDF of x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} itself, conditioned only on the check equations that relate x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} and its first tier variables, but using the results of step 1 as the PDF’s for the tier 1 variables. Hence, the results will be equivalent to conditioning on all the check equations.

There is a basic difference between the calculation in step 1 and step 2: the condition in step 2 involves all the check equations that are related to x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}, where in step 1 a single check equation is always omitted (the one that relates the relevant tier 1 element with x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} itself).

Assume now that there are many tiers, where each tier contains distinct elements of x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} (i.e. each element appears only once in the resulting tree). We can then start at the farthest tier and start moving toward x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}. We do it by repeatedly calculating step 1. After reaching tier 1, we use step 2 to finally calculate the desired conditional PDF for x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}.

This approach suggests an iterative algorithm for the calculation of f(xk|(y¯,s¯∈ℤn)f(x_{k}|(\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}) for k𝑘k=1,2..n1,2..n. In this approach we assume that the resulting tier diagram for each xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} contains distinct elements for several tiers (larger or equal to the number of required iterations). We then repeat step 1 several times, where the results of the previous iteration are used as initial PDF’s for the next iteration. Finally, we perform step 2 to calculate the final results.

Note that by conditioning only on part of the check equations in each iteration, we can not restrict the result to the shaping region. This is the reason that the decoder performs lattice decoding and not exact ML decoding, as described in Section III.

We shall now turn to derive the basic iteration of the algorithm. For simplicity, we shall start with the final step of the algorithm (denoted step 2 above). We would like to perform t𝑡t iterations, so assume that for each xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} there are t𝑡t tiers with a total of Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} check equations. For every xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} we need to calculate f​(xk|s¯∈ℤNc,y¯)=f​(xk|s¯(t​i​e​r1)∈ℤck,s¯(t​i​e​r2:t​i​e​rt)∈ℤNc−ck,y¯)𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘¯𝑠superscriptℤsubscript𝑁𝑐¯𝑦𝑓formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘superscript¯𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1superscriptℤsubscript𝑐𝑘superscript¯𝑠:𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟2𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟𝑡superscriptℤsubscript𝑁𝑐subscript𝑐𝑘¯𝑦f(x_{k}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}},\underline{y})=f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}-c_{k}},\underline{y}), where cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} is the number of check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}. s¯(t​i​e​r1)=Δ𝑯(t​i​e​r1)⋅x¯superscriptΔsuperscript¯𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1⋅superscript𝑯𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1¯𝑥\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}^{(tier_{1})}\cdot\underline{x} denotes the value of the left hand side of these check equations when x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} is substituted (𝑯(t​i​e​r1)superscript𝑯𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1\boldsymbol{H}^{(tier_{1})} is a submatrix of 𝑯𝑯\boldsymbol{H} that contains only the rows that relate to these check equations), and s¯(t​i​e​r2:t​i​e​rt)superscript¯𝑠:𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟2𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟𝑡\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})} relates in the same manner to all the other check equations. For simplicity of notations, denote the event s¯(t​i​e​r2:t​i​e​rt)∈ℤNc−cksuperscript¯𝑠:𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟2𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟𝑡superscriptℤsubscript𝑁𝑐subscript𝑐𝑘\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}-c_{k}} by A𝐴A. Using (27), we get:

This result can be summarized as follows. For each of the cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, the PDF’s (previous iteration results) of the active equation elements, except for xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} itself, are expanded and convolved, according to (C). The convolution result is scaled by (−hm,1)subscriptℎ𝑚1(-h_{m,1}), the negated coefficient of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} in this check equation, according to (37), to yield pm​(xk)subscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑥𝑘p_{m}(x_{k}). Then, a periodic function with period 1/|hm,1|1subscriptℎ𝑚11/|h_{m,1}| is generated by adding an infinite number of shifted versions of the scaled convolution result, according to the sum term in (38). After repeating this process for all the cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, we get cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} periodic functions, with possibly different periods. We then multiply all these functions. The multiplication result is further multiplied by the channel Gaussian PDF term e−(yk−xk)22​σ2superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘22superscript𝜎2e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}} and finally by f​(xk)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘f(x_{k}), the marginal PDF of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} under the i.i.d assumption. As discussed in Section III, we assume that f​(xk)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘f(x_{k}) is a uniform distribution with large enough range. This means that f​(xk)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘f(x_{k}) is constant over the valid range of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, and can therefore be omitted from (38) and absorbed in the constant C𝐶C.

As noted above, this result is for the final step (equivalent to step 2 above), where we determine the PDF of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} according to the PDF’s of all its tier 1 elements. However, the repeated iteration step is equivalent to step 1 above. In this step ,we assume that xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} is a tier 1 element of another element, say xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l}, and derive the PDF of xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} that should be used as input to step 2 of xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l} (see figure 2). It can be seen that the only difference between step 2 and step 1 is that in step 2 all the check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} are used, where in step 1 the check equation that involves both xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} and xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l} is ignored (there must be such an equation since xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} is one of the tier 1 elements of xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l}). Therefore, the step1 iteration is identical to (38), except that the product does not contain the term that corresponds to the check equation that combines both xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} and xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l}. Denote

fk​l​(xk)=Δf​(xk|s¯(t​i​e​r1​e​x​c​e​p​t​l)∈ℤck−1,A,y¯)superscriptΔsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘superscript¯𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1𝑒𝑥𝑐𝑒𝑝𝑡𝑙superscriptℤsubscript𝑐𝑘1𝐴¯𝑦\displaystyle f_{kl}(x_{k})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1}\ except\ l)}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}-1},A,\underline{y}) (39)

We then get:

fk​l​(xk)=C⋅e−(yk−xk)22​σ2​∏m=1m≠mlck∑im∈ℤpm​(xk−imhm,1)subscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝐶superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘22superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑚subscript𝑚𝑙subscript𝑐𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚ℤsubscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑖𝑚subscriptℎ𝑚1\displaystyle f_{kl}(x_{k})=C\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{\begin{subarray}{c}m=1\\ m\neq m_{l}\end{subarray}}^{c_{k}}\sum_{i_{m}\in\mathbb{Z}}p_{m}(x_{k}-\frac{i_{m}}{h_{m,1}}) (40)

where mlsubscript𝑚𝑙m_{l} is the index of the check equation that combines both xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} and xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l}. In principle, a different fk​l​(xk)subscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘f_{kl}(x_{k}) should be calculated for each xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l} for which xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} is a tier 1 element. However, the calculation is the same for all xlsubscript𝑥𝑙x_{l} that share the same check equation. Therefore, we should calculate fk​l​(xk)subscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘f_{kl}(x_{k}) once for each check equation that involves xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}. l𝑙l can be regarded as the index of the check equation within the set of check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}.

We can now formulate the iterative decoder. The decoder state variables are PDF’s of the form fk​l(t)​(xk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘f^{(t)}_{kl}(x_{k}), where k=1,2,…​n𝑘12…𝑛k=1,2,...n. For each k𝑘k, l𝑙l assumes the values 1,2,…​ck12…subscript𝑐𝑘1,2,...c_{k}, where cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} is the number of check equations that involve xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}. t𝑡t denotes the iteration index. For a regular LDLC with degree d𝑑d there will be n​d𝑛𝑑nd PDF’s. The PDF’s are initialized by assuming that xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} is a leaf of the tier diagram. Such a leaf has no tier 1 elements, so fk​l​(xk)=f​(xk)⋅f​(yk|xk)subscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘f_{kl}(x_{k})=f(x_{k})\cdot f(y_{k}|x_{k}). As explained above for equation (38), we shall omit the term f​(xk)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘f(x_{k}), resulting in initialization with the channel noise Gaussian around the noisy observation yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}. Then, the PDF’s are updated in each iteration according to (40). The variable node messages should be further normalized in order to get actual PDF’s, such that ∫−∞∞fk​l​(xk)​𝑑xk=1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑙subscript𝑥𝑘differential-dsubscript𝑥𝑘1\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f_{kl}(x_{k})dx_{k}=1 (this will compensate for the constant C𝐶C). The final PDF’s for xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}, k=1,2,…​n𝑘12…𝑛k=1,2,...n are then calculated according to (38).

Finally, we have to estimate the integer valued information vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b}. This can be done by first estimating the codeword vector x¯¯𝑥\underline{x} from the peaks of the PDF’s: xk^=a​r​g​maxxk⁡f​(xk|s¯(t​i​e​r1)∈ℤck,A,y¯)^subscript𝑥𝑘𝑎𝑟𝑔subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑓conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑘superscript¯𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑒subscript𝑟1superscriptℤsubscript𝑐𝑘𝐴¯𝑦\hat{x_{k}}=arg\max_{x_{k}}f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},A,\underline{y}). Finally, we can estimate b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} as b¯^=⌊𝑯x¯^⌉\underline{\hat{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\underline{\hat{x}}\right\rceil.

We have finished developing the iterative algorithm. It can be easily seen that the message passing formulation of Section III-A actually implements this algorithm.

Appendix D Asymptotic Behavior of the Variances Recursion

D-A Proof of Lemma 3 and Lemma 4

We shall now derive the basic iterative equations that relate the variances at iteration t+1𝑡1t+1 to the variances at iteration t𝑡t for a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n, degree d𝑑d and generating sequence h1≥h2≥…≥hd>0subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑑0h_{1}\geq h_{2}\geq...\geq h_{d}>0.

Each iteration, every check node generates d𝑑d output messages, one for each variable node that is connected to it, where the weights of these d𝑑d connections are ±h1,±h2,…,±hdplus-or-minussubscriptℎ1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ2…plus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑑\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the check node convolves d−1𝑑1d-1 expanded variable node PDF messages, and then stretches and periodically extends the result. For a specific check node, denote the variance of the variable node message that arrives along an edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} by Vj(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑗V^{(t)}_{j}, j=1,2,…​d𝑗12…𝑑j=1,2,...d. Denote the variance of the message that is sent back to a variable node along an edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} by V~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑗\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}. From (1), (3), we get:

V~j(t)=1hj2​∑i=1i≠jdhi2​Vi(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑗1superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{1}{h_{j}^{2}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{i}^{2}V^{(t)}_{i} (41)

for i=1,2,…​d𝑖12…𝑑i=1,2,...d, which completes the proof of Lemma 4.

Claim 3

For every t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, the first variables of the two sets are related by V1(t)≥U1(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡1V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1}, where for i=2,3,…​d𝑖23…𝑑i=2,3,...d we have Vi(t)≤Ui(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡𝑖V^{(t)}_{i}\leq U^{(t)}_{i}.

Proof:

Assume now that the relations are satisfied for iteration t𝑡t, i.e. V1(t)≥U1(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡1V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1} and for i=2,3,…​d𝑖23…𝑑i=2,3,...d, Vi(t)≤Ui(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡𝑖V^{(t)}_{i}\leq U^{(t)}_{i}. If we now compare the right hand side of the update recursion for 1V1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡11\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{1}} to that of 1U1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡11\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{1}} (i.e. (4) to (44)), then the right hand side for 1V1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡11\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{1}} is smaller, because it has additional positive terms in the denominators, where the common terms in the denominators are larger according to the induction assumption. Therefore, V1(t+1)≥U1(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡11subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡11V^{(t+1)}_{1}\geq U^{(t+1)}_{1}, as required. Therefore, Vi(t+1)≤Ui(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡1𝑖V^{(t+1)}_{i}\leq U^{(t+1)}_{i} for i=2,3,…​d𝑖23…𝑑i=2,3,...d, as required. ∎

Using claim 3 and the analytic results for Ui(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡𝑖U^{(t)}_{i}, we now have:

V1(t)≥U1(t)=σ2​(1−α)​11−αt+1≥σ2​(1−α)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑡1superscript𝜎21𝛼11superscript𝛼𝑡1superscript𝜎21𝛼\displaystyle V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1}=\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)\frac{1}{1-\alpha^{t+1}}\geq\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) (46)

We have shown that the first variance is lower bounded by a positive nonzero constant where the other variances are upper bounded by a term that decays exponentially to zero. Therefore, for large t𝑡t we have Vi(t)<<V1(t)much-less-thansubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡1V^{(t)}_{i}<<V^{(t)}_{1} and Vi(t)<<σ2much-less-thansubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑖superscript𝜎2V^{(t)}_{i}<<\sigma^{2} for i=2,3,…​d𝑖23…𝑑i=2,3,...d. It then follows that for large t𝑡t the variances approximately obey the recursion (44), which was built from the actual variance recursion (4) under these assumptions. Therefore, for i=2,3,…​d𝑖23…𝑑i=2,3,...d the variances are not only upper bounded by an exponentially decaying term, but actually approach such a term, where the first variance actually approaches the constant σ2​(1−α)superscript𝜎21𝛼\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) in an exponential rate. This completes the proof of Theorem 1.

Note that the above analysis only applies if α<1𝛼1\alpha<1. To illustrate the behavior for α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1, consider the simple case of h1=h2=…=hdsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑑h_{1}=h_{2}=...=h_{d}. It can be seen that all the variances converge to zero, but with slow convergence rate of o​(1/t)𝑜1𝑡o(1/t).

Appendix E Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean Values Recursion

E-A Proof of Lemma 5 and Lemma 6 (Mean of Narrow Messages)

Assume a magic square LDLC with dimension n𝑛n and degree d𝑑d. We shall now examine the effect of the calculations in the check nodes and variable nodes on the mean values and derive the resulting recursion. Every iteration, each check node generates d𝑑d output messages, one for each variable node that connects to it, where the weights of these d𝑑d connections are ±h1,±h2,…,±hdplus-or-minussubscriptℎ1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ2…plus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑑\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the check node convolves d−1𝑑1d-1 expanded variable node PDF messages, and then stretches and periodically extends the result. We shall concentrate on the n​d𝑛𝑑nd consistent Gaussians that relate to the same integer vector b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} (one Gaussian in each message), and analyze them jointly. For convenience, we shall refer to the mean value of the relevant consistent Gaussian as the mean of the message.

Consider now a specific check node. Denote the mean value of the variable node message that arrives at iteration t𝑡t along the edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} by mj(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡𝑗m^{(t)}_{j}, j=1,2,…​d𝑗12…𝑑j=1,2,...d. Denote the mean value of the message that is sent back to a variable node along an edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} by m~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑗\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}. From (1), (3) and claim 1, we get:

m~j(t)=1hj​(bk−∑i=1i≠jdhi​mi(t))subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑗1subscriptℎ𝑗subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑑subscriptℎ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{1}{h_{j}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{i}m^{(t)}_{i}\right) (48)

where bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} is the appropriate element of b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that is related to this specific check equation, which is the only relevant index in the infinite sum of the periodic extension step (3). Note that the check node operation is equivalent to extracting the value of mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j} from the check equation ∑i=1dhi​mi=bksuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptℎ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘\sum_{i=1}^{d}h_{i}m_{i}=b_{k}, assuming all the other misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} are known. Note also that the coefficients hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} should have a random sign. To keep notations simple, we assume that hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} already includes the random sign. Later, when several equations will be combined together, we should take it into account.

Then, each variable node generates d𝑑d messages, one for each check node that is connected to it, where the weights of these d𝑑d connections are ±h1,±h2,…,±hdplus-or-minussubscriptℎ1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ2…plus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑑\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the variable node generates the product of d−1𝑑1d-1 check node messages and the channel noise PDF. For a specific variable node, denote the mean value of the message that arrives from a check node along an edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} by m~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑗\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}, and the appropriate variance by V~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑗\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}. The mean value of the message that is sent back to a check node along an edge with weight ±hjplus-or-minussubscriptℎ𝑗\pm h_{j} is mj(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡1𝑗m^{(t+1)}_{j}, the final mean value of the iteration. From claim 2, we then get:

mj(t+1)=yk/σ2+∑i=1i≠jdm~i(t)/V~i(t)1/σ2+∑i=1i≠jd1/V~i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡1𝑗subscript𝑦𝑘superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑑subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑖1superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑑1subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑖\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{j}=\frac{y_{k}/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{i}/\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}}{1/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}1/\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}} (49)

where yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is the channel observation for the variable node and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the noise variance. Note that m~i(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡𝑖\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,…,d𝑖12…𝑑i=1,2,...,d in (49) are the mean values of check node messages that arrive to the same variable node from different check nodes, where in (48) they define the mean values of check node messages that leave the same check node. However, it is beneficial to keep the notations simple, and we shall take special care when (49) and (48) are combined.

It can be seen that the convergence of the mean values is coupled to the convergence of the variances (unlike the recursion of the variances which was autonomous). However, as the iterations go on, this coupling disappears. To see that, recall from Theorem 1 that for each check node, the variance of the variable node message that comes along an edge with weight ±h1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ1\pm h_{1} approaches a finite value, where the variance of all the other messages approaches zero exponentially. According to (41), the variance of the check node message is a weighted sum of the variances of the incoming variable node messages. Therefore, the variance of the check node message that goes along an edge with weight ±h1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ1\pm h_{1} will approach zero, since the weighted sum involves only zero-approaching variances. All the other messages will have finite variance, since the weighted sum involves the non zero-approaching variance. To summarize, each variable node sends (and each check node receives) d−1𝑑1d-1 “narrow” messages and a single “wide” message. Each check node sends (and each variable node receives) d−1𝑑1d-1 “wide” messages and a single “narrow” message, where the narrow message is sent along the edge from which the wide message was received (the edge with weight ±h1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ1\pm h_{1}).

We shall now concentrate on the case where the variable node generates a narrow message. Then, the sum in the nominator of (49) has a single term for which V~i(t)→0→subscriptsuperscript~𝑉𝑡𝑖0\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}\rightarrow 0, which corresponds to i=1𝑖1i=1. The same is true for the sum in the denominator. Therefore, for large t𝑡t, all the other terms will become negligible and we get:

mj(t+1)≈m~1(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡1𝑗subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡1\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{j}\approx\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{1} (50)

where m~1(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑚𝑡1\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{1} is the mean of the message that comes from the edge with weight h1subscriptℎ1h_{1}, i.e. the narrow check node message. As discussed above, d−1𝑑1d-1 of the d𝑑d variable node messages that leave the same variable node are narrow. From (50) it comes out that for large t𝑡t, all these d−1𝑑1d-1 narrow messages will have the same mean value. This completes the proof of Lemma 5.

Now, combining (48) and (50) (where the indices are arranged again, as discussed above), we get:

ml1(t+1)≈1h1​(bk−∑i=2dhi​mli(t))subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡1subscript𝑙11subscriptℎ1subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑑subscriptℎ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑙𝑖\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{l_{1}}\approx\frac{1}{h_{1}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}m^{(t)}_{l_{i}}\right) (51)

where lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}, i=1,2​…,d𝑖12…𝑑i=1,2...,d are the variable nodes that take place in the check equation for which variable node l1subscript𝑙1l_{1} appears with coefficient ±h1plus-or-minussubscriptℎ1\pm h_{1}. bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} is the element of b¯¯𝑏\underline{b} that is related to this check equation. ml1(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡1subscript𝑙1m^{(t+1)}_{l_{1}} denotes the mean value of the d−1𝑑1d-1 narrow messages that leave variable node l1subscript𝑙1l_{1} at iteration t+1𝑡1t+1. mli(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑙𝑖m^{(t)}_{l_{i}} is the mean value of the narrow messages that were generated at variable node lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i} at iteration t𝑡t. Only narrow messages are involved in (51), because the right hand side of (50) is the mean value of the narrow check node message that arrived to variable node l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}, which results from the convolution of d−1𝑑1d-1 narrow variable node messages. Therefore, for large t𝑡t, the mean values of the narrow messages are decoupled from the mean values of the wide messages (and also from the variances), and they obey an autonomous recursion.

The mean values of the narrow messages at iteration t𝑡t can be arranged in an n𝑛n-element column vector m¯(t)superscript¯𝑚𝑡\underline{m}^{(t)} (one mean value for each variable node). Appendix F Asymptotic Behavior of the Amplitudes Recursion

F-A Proof of Lemma 9

From (13), ai(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖a^{(t)}_{i} is clearly non-negative. From Sections IV-B, IV-C (and the appropriate appendices) it comes out that for consistent Gaussians, the mean values and variances of the messages have a finite bounded value and converge to a finite steady state value. The excitation term ai(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑡𝑖a^{(t)}_{i} depends on these mean values and variances according to (13), so it is also finite and bounded, and it converges to a steady state value, where caution should be taken for the case of a zero approaching variance. Note that at most a single variance in (13) may approach zero (as explained in Section IV-B, a single narrow check node message is used for the generation of narrow variable node messages, and only wide check node messages are used for the generation of wide variable node messages). Therefore, for d>2𝑑2d>2 the infinite sum will have a finite steady state value. This completes the proof of Lemma 9.
