Appendix H Reducing the Complexity of the FFT Calculations

FFT calculation can be made simpler by using the fact that the convolution is followed by the following steps: the convolution result p~j​(x)subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) is stretched to pj​(x)=p~j​(−hj​x)subscript𝑝𝑗𝑥subscript~𝑝𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗𝑥p_{j}(x)=\tilde{p}_{j}(-h_{j}x) and then periodically extended to Qj​(x)=∑i=−∞∞pj​(x−ihj)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗𝑥𝑖subscriptℎ𝑗Q_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}p_{j}\left(x-\frac{i}{h_{j}}\right) (see (3)). It can be seen that the stretching and periodic extension steps can be exchanged, and the convolution result p~j​(x)subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) can be first periodically extended with period 111 to Q~j​(x)=∑i=−∞∞p~j​(x+i)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥𝑖\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{j}\left(x+i\right) and then stretched to Qj​(x)=Q~j​(−hj​x)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥subscript~𝑄𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗𝑥Q_{j}(x)=\tilde{Q}_{j}(-h_{j}x). Now, the infinite sum can be written as a convolution with a sequence of Dirac impulses:

Q~j​(x)=∑i=−∞∞p~j​(x+i)=p~j​(x)⊛∑i=−∞∞δ​(x+i)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥𝑖⊛subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖𝛿𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{j}\left(x+i\right)=\tilde{p}_{j}(x)\circledast\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\delta(x+i) (76)

Therefore, the Fourier transform of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) will equal the Fourier transform of p~j​(x)subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) multiplied by the Fourier transform of the impulse sequence, which is itself an impulse sequence. The FFT of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) will therefore have several nonzero values, separated by sequences of zeros. These nonzero values will equal the FFT of p~j​(x)subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) after decimation. To ensure an integer decimation rate, we should choose the PDF resolution ΔΔ\Delta such that an interval with range 111 (the period of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)) will contain an integer number of samples, i.e. 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta should be an integer. Also, we should choose L𝐿L (the number of samples in Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)) to correspond to a range which equals an integer, i.e. D=L⋅Δ𝐷⋅𝐿ΔD=L\cdot\Delta should be an integer. Then, we can calculate the (size L) FFT of p~j​(x)subscript~𝑝𝑗𝑥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) and then decimate by D𝐷D. The result will give 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta samples which correspond to a single period (with range 1) of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x).

However, instead of calculating an FFT of length L𝐿L and immediately decimating, we can directly calculate the decimated FFT. Denote the expanded PDF at the convolution input by f~ksubscript~𝑓𝑘\tilde{f}_{k}, k=1,2,…​L𝑘12…𝐿k=1,2,...L (where the expanded PDF is zero padded to length L𝐿L). To generate directly the decimated result, we can first calculate the (size D𝐷D) FFT of each group of D𝐷D samples which are generated by decimating f~ksubscript~𝑓𝑘\tilde{f}_{k} by L/D=1/Δ𝐿𝐷1ΔL/D=1/\Delta. Then, the desired decimated result is the FFT (of size 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta) of the sequence of first samples of each FFT of size D𝐷D. However, The first sample of an FFT is simply the sum of its inputs. Therefore, we should only calculate the sequence (of length 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta) gi=∑k=0D−1f~i+k/Δsubscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐷1subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑘Δg_{i}=\sum_{k=0}^{D-1}\tilde{f}_{i+k/\Delta}, i=1,2,…​1/Δ𝑖12…1Δi=1,2,...1/\Delta and then calculate the FFT (of length 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta) of the result. This is done for all the expanded PDF’s. Then, d−1𝑑1d-1 such results are multiplied, and an IFFT (of length 1/Δ1Δ1/\Delta) gives a single period of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x).

With this method, instead of calculating d𝑑d FFT’s and d𝑑d IFFT’s of size larger than L𝐿L, we calculate d𝑑d FFT’s and d𝑑d IFFT’s of size L/D=1/Δ𝐿𝐷1ΔL/D=1/\Delta.

In order to generate the final check node message, we should stretch Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) to Qj​(x)=Q~j​(−hj​x)subscript𝑄𝑗𝑥subscript~𝑄𝑗subscriptℎ𝑗𝑥Q_{j}(x)=\tilde{Q}_{j}(-h_{j}x). This can be done by interpolating a single period of Q~j​(x)subscript~𝑄𝑗𝑥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) using interpolation methods similar to those that were used in Section VI for expanding the variable node PDF’s.
